list.title: Question 1
list.content:
What is a disadvantage to an organism of being multicellular rather than unicellular?


- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Larger body size
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Ability to adapt to their surroundings
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The need for a complex exchange system
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Cell differentiation
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Multicellular organisms are comprised of numerous specialised cells, enabling them to achieve larger sizes compared to unicellular organisms. This results in them needing exchange systems, such as the circulatory and respiratory systems, to manage waste removal and to acquire essential substances such as oxygen and nutrients. In contrast, unicellular organisms can rely on simple diffusion. Choice C  is correct.
Choice A  is incorrect because although multicellular organisms often have a larger body size than unicellular organisms, this can be advantageous to them. Choice B  is incorrect, as multicellular organisms adapting to their environment more easily is an advantage. Choice D  is incorrect, as cell differentiation, where cells become specialised for specific functions, is an advantage as it allows for the division of labour amongst cells.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Which statement about eukaryotic cells is correct?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic chromosomes are circular and the DNA is associated with histone proteins
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic cells have looped DNA molecules which are not associated with proteins in the nucleus
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic cells have linear DNA molecules associated with proteins
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ Eukaryotic cells have linear DNA molecules that are not associated with histone proteins
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The chromosomes of eukaryotes are linear, and the DNA is coiled around histone proteins (Choice C). Choice A is incorrect because eukaryotic DNA molecules are not circular. Choice B  is incorrect because eukaryotic cells do not have looped DNA in the nucleus. Choice D  is incorrect because the linear DNA molecules in eukaryotic cells are coiled around histone proteins.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
What type of cell is shown in the image?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb7991c0-6eee-4fa1-81bc-74345942fcf6/images/be97c032-ac41-4e78-8ebb-0e74c97826e6/BI0392ii.png)


[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia. (2016, March 1). Category: Electron Microscope Images. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved May 19, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscopy.jpg  Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ A eukaryotic cell because it contains mitochondria
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ A prokaryotic cell because it has a plasma membrane
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ A eukaryotic cell because it does not have a nucleus
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ A prokaryotic cell because it contains ribosomes
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Eukaryotic cells contain mitochondria but prokaryotic cells do not. Choice A is correct.
Choices B and D are incorrect as the cell is not prokaryotic; it has a nucleus. Choice C is incorrect because the cell has a nucleus.

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Which statement(s) about the endosymbiotic theory is/are true?


- I. $\hspace{1em}$	It provides evidence for the origin of prokaryotes.
- II. $\hspace{.7em}$	It provides evidence for the origin of eukaryotes.
- III. $\hspace{.5em}$	It provides evidence for spontaneous generation.




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	I only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria, eventually evolving into eukaryotes. Choice A is correct.
Statement I (Choices B and D) is incorrect as prokaryotes were not formed by the endosymbiotic theory. Statement III (Choice C) is incorrect as spontaneous generation is impossible.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Which structure in a eukaryotic cell would also be present in a prokaryotic cell?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Nucleus
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Plasma membrane
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 80S ribosomes
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Histones
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells contain a plasma membrane; Choice B  is correct.
Choices A, C and D  are incorrect as they are present in eukaryotic cells but not prokaryotic cells.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Which row in the table correctly identifies structures which are present (✓) or absent (✕)  in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

StructureProkaryotic cellsEukaryotic cellsA.$\hspace{1em}$70S Ribosomes in Cytosol✓✕B.$\hspace{1em}$Cell Wall✕✓C.$\hspace{1em}$Mitochondria✓✕D.$\hspace{1em}$Naked DNA✕✓
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Prokaryotic cells contain 70S ribosomes in their cytoplasm, while eukaryotic cells have 80s cytoplasmic ribosomes, so Choice A is correct.
Choice B is incorrect as prokaryotes have a cell wall, but not all eukaryotes do. Choice C is incorrect as prokaryotes do not contain membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, but eukaryotes do. *Choice D is incorrect, as prokaryotic cells have naked DNA, whereas eukaryotic cells contain DNA within a nuclear membrane.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
These photographs show the same section of a human retina. What is the reason for the difference between the two diagrams?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/34eb27e0-6237-4360-ac56-27073683e781/images/58faa56f-a89c-49e0-824a-bfbe19119bb9/BI0391_1.2.png)


[Source: Nestl, A. (2012, January 17). File AMD Super resolution Cremer.png - Wikimedia Commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved June 16, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Opthalmology_AMD_Super_Resolution_Cremer.png Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ The photograph on the right was taken using an electron microscope.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ The photograph on the right is at a higher resolution.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ The photograph on the right is at a higher magnification.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ The photograph on the right shows the ultrastructure of the cells.
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The resolution is the ability to distinguish between two objects. Choice B is correct.
Choices A and D are incorrect because a photograph taken using an electron microscope would allow the ultrastructure of the cells (fine detail of cells, such as organelles) to be observed. Choice C is incorrect because these photographs are magnified at the same power.

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Which of the following correctly describes the images produced by electron microscopes?


- I.High resolutionII.High magnificationIII.Coloured




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Electron micrographs have high resolution (Statement I) and high magnification (Statement II) Choice B is therefore correct.
Electron micrographs are not coloured (Statement III). Choice A is incorrect as it only includes one correct statement.  Choices C and D are incorrect because they include Statement III.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Paramecium produces enzymes that catalyse different chemical reactions taking place in the cytoplasm. What function of life is demonstrated in this situation?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Excretion
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Homeostasis
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Reproduction
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Metabolism
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A - Excretion is the removal of metabolic wastes from the organism. Paramecia expel waste products such as carbon dioxide through the process of diffusion.
Choice B - Homeostasis pertains to the ability of living things to maintain a stable internal environment. Paramecia maintain a stable internal condition by expelling excess water using the contractile vacuole.
Choice C -   Reproduction is the biological process by which organisms produce offspring that are biologically similar to themselves. Paramecia can reproduce sexually through meiosis and asexually through mitosis.
Choice D - Metabolism refers to all the chemical reactions in organisms such as anabolic and catabolic reactions. Paramecia produce enzymes that catalyse different catabolic and anabolic reactions in the cell.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Which organelle has a double membrane?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Rough endoplasmic reticulum
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	Golgi apparatus
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	Nucleus
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Vacuole
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The nucleus is the only organelle among the options listed that has a double membrane. The nuclear envelope consists of two lipid bilayers: the inner membrane and the outer membrane. Choice C is correct.
Choices A, B and D are incorrect as they all have a single membrane.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Which structure found in a eukaryote has a double membrane?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Golgi apparatus
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Mitochondrion
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Lysosome
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Endoplasmic reticulum
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Organelles of a eukaryotic cell are enclosed by a single or double membrane. Double membrane-bound organelles include the nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts. So, a mitochondrion has a double membrane.
The Golgi apparatus (Choice A), lysosome (Choice C), and endoplasmic reticulum (Choice D) all have a single membrane.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
The photomicrograph shows Chlorella, the cells of which contain chlorophyll.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a549579f-5d03-4a34-99a1-cdcb73fb3959/images/f787f899-db4e-48d7-9c4c-fc7fb4e26e99/image.png)


Magnification: 100 x $\hspace{3em}$Scale bar = 10 µm[Source: Adapted from User: NEON. (2014). Chlorella vulgaris Beijerinck Nies-2170 / Olympus IX71+DP72. Wikimedia Common. Retrieved April 6, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Chlorella_vulgaris_NIES2170.jpg. Copyright by CC BY-SA 3.0]


Which statement best explains how chlorophyll supports a function of life?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ It catalyses the breakdown of glucose into ATP.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$  It absorbs light energy needed to convert inorganic molecules into organic molecules.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ It transports carbon dioxide into the chloroplast for glucose synthesis.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ It stores the energy released during cellular respiration.
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B accurately describes chlorophyll’s role in photosynthesis, a process that supports the life function of nutrition in autotrophic organisms (like plants and some unicellular organisms). Chlorophyll absorbs light energy, which is used to convert inorganic carbon dioxide and water into the organic compound glucose.
Choice A is incorrect because this describes cellular respiration, not the function of chlorophyll.
The breakdown of glucose into ATP happens in the mitochondria and does not use chlorophyll.
Choice C is incorrect because chlorophyll does not transport carbon dioxide; CO₂ enters the leaf via stomata and diffuses into chloroplasts. Chlorophyll’s role is to absorb light, not transport gases.
Choice D is incorrect because chlorophyll is involved in capturing light energy, not in storing energy from respiration. Energy from respiration is stored in ATP, not in chlorophyll.

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Which of the following statements is true of fungal cell walls?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ They are composed of cellulose.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Fungal cells do not have cell walls.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ They are composed of chitin.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ They are composed of peptidoglycan.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because fungal cell walls are primarily composed of chitin. Choice A is incorrect because cellulose is the main carbohydrate that makes up plant cell walls. Peptidoglycan is found in bacterial cell walls, so Choice D is incorrect. Fungal cells do have cell walls, so Choice B is incorrect.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Which of the following statements are true about the structure of cells?


- I.All cells contain cytoplasm enclosed by the plasma membrane.II.The microscope was important in understanding the structure of the cell.III.Prokaryotes do not have genetic material.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is true because all cells have cytoplasm enclosed by the plasma membrane.
Statement II is also true because the invention of the microscope made viewing structures within the cell easier.
Statement III is false because all cells have genetic material. Eukaryotic cells have their genetic material inside of the nucleus, while prokaryotes have their genetic material in the nucleoid region.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
Below is a micrograph of a bacterium, Marinomonas arctica, which is found in Arctic sea ice.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e4c4e564-261e-4307-9a32-e06985877dc5/images/c403239f-99bf-4c69-919f-90bc200a737a/BI1258.png)


[Source: Gulf of Alaska Seamounts expedition, 2019. Marinomonas arctica.jpg. Wikimedia. Retrieved, September 25th 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Marinomonas_arctica.jpg. Copyright under Public Domain]
Which row contains features of prokaryotic cells such as Marinomonas arctica?

RibosomesCell wallDNA associated with proteinsA.$\hspace{1em}$80SYesNoB.$\hspace{1em}$80SYesYesC.$\hspace{1em}$70SNoNoD.$\hspace{1em}$70SYesNo
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because bacteria are prokaryotes, and prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes and a cell wall; they do not have proteins associated with the DNA. Choice A is incorrect because prokaryotes do not have 80S ribosomes. Choice B is incorrect because prokaryotes do not have 80S ribosomes or proteins associated with DNA. Choice C is incorrect because prokaryotes do have cell walls.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Which statement(s) is/are not true of eukaryotic or prokaryotic cells?


- I. $\hspace{1em}$ Prokaryotic cells have a compartmentalised structure.
- II.$\hspace{.8em}$ Only eukaryotic cells have a Golgi apparatus.
- III.$\hspace{.6em}$ Only eukaryotic cells have membrane-bound organelles.




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	I only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	I, II and III
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is NOT true of prokaryotic cells because they do not have compartmentalised structures. Compartmentalisation is a defining feature of eukaryotic cells, allowing them to carry out more complex and specialised functions.
Statement II is true of prokaryotic cells because they do not have a Golgi apparatus. The Golgi apparatus is a membrane-bound organelle, and only eukaryotic cells possess it.
Statement III is true because membrane-bound organelles is a defining feature of eukaryotic cells. Prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles entirely.
Choice B is the correct answer as it only includes Statement I.
Choices A, C and D are incorrect as they all include Statement II, Statement III or both.

list.markScheme: - any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ arrow A points to the plasma membrane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ arrow B points to the nucleus (in white blood cell) [1] [2 marks maximum] - Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ consists of different types of cells OR consists of specialised cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ consists of red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets [1] [1 mark maximum] Sample answer: The definition of tissue is different types of cells working together ($\checkmark$). Blood consists of red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets,($\checkmark$) which each have a different role and work together. - $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ bone marrow [1] [1 mark maximum] - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ through selective gene expression OR expression of only tissue-specific genes OR expression of specific genes needed for the development of the blood cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in response to changes in the environment [1] $\ce{ -> }$ become specialised cells OR become cells with a specific role OR function [1] $\ce{ -> }$ differentiate into red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets OR become the different types of blood cells [1] [2 marks maximum] Sample answer: Through selective gene expression ($\checkmark$) common progenitor cells become specialised cells ($\checkmark$). In the case of blood, these cells differentiate into red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
Which statement applies to both mitochondria and prokaryotes?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ They both contain DNA.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	They both have flagella.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	They both contain lysosomes.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	They both have a cell wall.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Mitochondria and prokaryotes both contain their own DNA (Choice A).
Choices B, C and D are incorrect as they are all only present in prokaryotes but not in mitochondria.

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
The electron micrograph shows tobacco leaf mesophyll cells.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/277f4f8c-19fc-469f-b9a4-3305fde9bb35/images/b7225a3a-fdc9-4f9f-a955-1e86a3c869ff/BI1557.png)


[Adapted from: Marys, E. (n.d.). A Ultrathin Section of Vegetal Leaf Mesophyll Cells Showing Chloroplast Structure Stock Image - Image of discovery, botany: 211880559. Dreamstime.com. Retrieved April 23, 2024, from https://www.dreamstime.com/ultra-thin-section-transmission-electron-microscopy-tobacco-leaf-mesophyll-cells-showing-chloroplast-structure-ultrathin-image211880559. Royalty free image.]

Identify structures X, Y, and Z in the micrograph.
Structure XStructure YStructure ZA.$\hspace{1em}$mitochondrionnucleusplasma membraneB.$\hspace{1em}$chloroplastvacuolecell wallC.$\hspace{1em}$mitochondrionvacuoleplasma membraneD.$\hspace{1em}$chloroplastnucleuscell wall
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because structure X is a chloroplast, structure Y is the nucleus and structure Z is the cell wall.
Choice A is incorrect because X is a chloroplast, not a mitochondrion. Choice B is incorrect because Y is the nucleus, not a vacuole. Choice C is incorrect because both structures X and Y are mislabelled.

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Which structure is found in both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Lysosome
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Ribosome
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Golgi apparatus
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Nucleoid
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Unlike eukaryotes, prokaryotes lack a nucleus and membrane-bound organelles. However, like eukaryotes, prokaryotes contain ribosomes, a non-membrane-bound organelle required for protein synthesis. So, ribosomes are found in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
Lysosomes (Choice A) and the Golgi apparatus (Choice C) are only found in eukaryotes. The nucleoid (Choice D) is only found in prokaryotes.

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
What is the actual width of the cell in this image? The scale bar represents 5μm.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6b591b07-f59c-48c2-9596-d40067442d9b/images/bc4aab5d-8d13-40de-a819-a662fa2d63b0/BI1135.png)


[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia (2006, March 1). File: Electron Microscope Siemens, 1960.jpg - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved March 4, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscope_Siemens,_1960.jpg Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 4μm
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 40μm
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 400μm
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 4000μm
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The scale bar is shown to be 5μm in width, which is represented by 0.5cm on the ruler. The ruler indicates a total cell width of 4cm. Therefore, 8 scale bar widths will fit within the cell. Actual cell width = 8 $\times$ 5μm = 40μm.
Choices A, C, and D are incorrect.

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Mesophyll cells are found in plants. Plant cells have unique characteristics that distinguish them from any other cell type.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/860825df-c83f-42a2-959f-858276f1b357/images/a1726d87-2824-4bf2-b6bb-b3a42c682716/BI0575.png)

[Source: Adapted from Zhang, N., Zhang, L., Zhao, L., Ren, Y., Cui, D., Chen, J., ... & Chen, F. (2017). iTRAQ and virus-induced gene silencing revealed three proteins involved in the cold response in bread wheat. Scientific reports, 7(1), 1-16.Retrieved March 27, 2022. From https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5548720/. Copyright under CC by 4.0]
In the micrograph above, one of the cell parts is labelled X. What is the name of this structure?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Chloroplast
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Central vacuole
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Cell wall
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Starch granule
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C - The cell wall is the outermost layer of plant cells just outside the plasma membrane.
Chloroplasts (Choice A) are membrane-bound oval-shaped organelles (labelled Ch in the image) that are responsible for photosynthesis.
The central vacuole (Choice B) is located in the centre of the cell, not towards the outside.  It is evident in the micrograph provided by the white, empty space in the middle of the cell.
Starch granules (Choice D) are structures consisting of starch.  Their function is to store starch which is produced during photosynthesis. Starch granules are not visible in the micrgraph above.

Copyright under Public Domain] - - Explain how the structure of this cell is related to the function of the synthesis of proteins for release from the cell. [2] - State why an electron microscope is needed to view the ultrastructure of the acinar cells. [2]
list.markScheme: - - Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ large number of chloroplasts [1] $\ce{ -> }$ large surface area [1] $\ce{ -> }$ air spaces OR spongy mesophyll [1] $\ce{ -> }$ vascular tissues OR veins OR vascular bundles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ stomata OR guard cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ waxy cuticle [1] $\ce{ -> }$ columnar cells in top layer OR palisade mesophylll [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The leaf has a large surface area ($\checkmark$) for absorption of light. - - $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The organelle in greater abundance in the palisade mesophyll cells is the chloroplast ($\checkmark$). - - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ nucleus separated from cytoplasm by membrane AND allowing post-transcriptional modification of mRNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ large numbers of membrane-bound ribosomes OR rough endoplasmic reticulum AND for translation OR synthesis of proteins for secretion [1] $\ce{ -> }$ large amount of rough endoplasmic reticulum AND lumen of rough endoplasmic reticulum is where polypeptides are folded and modified to form proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ many vesicles AND used to transport proteins from rough endoplasmic reticulum to Golgi apparatus OR to carry proteins to plasma OR cell membrane for secretion [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Golgi apparatus AND receives proteins from rough endoplasmic reticulum and modifies OR packages proteins for release from cell [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The structure of this cell is adapted to its function because it contains a large amount of rough endoplasmic reticulum. The ribosomes on the rough endoplasmic reticulum are the site of the synthesis of the polypeptides ($\checkmark$) and these polypeptides are then folded and modified into functional proteins in the lumen of the rough endoplasmic reticulum ($\checkmark$). - - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ electron microscopes have a higher resolution than light microscopes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ electron microscopes have a higher magnification than light microscopes [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Electron microscopes have higher magnification ($\checkmark$) and higher resolution ($\checkmark$) than light microscopes, so they allow more detail to be seen in smaller objects.

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
Which row correctly describes the DNA and chromosomes of Eubacteria cells?

ShapeDNA with histonesNumber of chromosomes$\hspace{1em}$A.$\hspace{1em}$CircularYesMore than one$\hspace{1em}$B.$\hspace{1em}$LinearYesMore than one$\hspace{1em}$C.$\hspace{1em}$CircularNoOne$\hspace{1em}$D.$\hspace{1em}$LinearNoOne
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Eubacteria have a single chromosome composed of DNA and not associated with histones(Choice C).
Choice A is incorrect because prokaryotes' DNA is not associated with histones and they only have one chromosome. Choice B is incorrect because prokaryotes do not have linear DNA, their DNA is not associated with histones, and they do not have more than one chromosome. Choice D is incorrect because prokaryotic chromosomes are not linear.

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
Cyanobacteria are prokaryotes that can perform photosynthesis. Which structural feature is common to both cyanobacteria and plant cells?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Chloroplast
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Cell wall
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Pili
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Mitochondria
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Prokaryotes are one of the earliest organisms to have evolved the process of photosynthesis. Plant cells are eukaryotes that can also perform photosynthesis, but they evolved after prokaryotes. Some of the features that distinguish prokaryotes from plant cells (which are eukaryotes) are membrane-bound organelles such as chloroplasts (Choice A) and mitochondria (Choice D) which are present in plant cells but absent in prokaryotes. According to the endosymbiotic theory, cyanobacteria evolved into chloroplasts during the early evolutionary process of eukaryotic cells.
Pili are found in prokaryotes but not in plant cells (Choice C). Even though the composition of the cell wall in prokaryotes is different (made of a peptidoglycan polymer) from the cell wall in plant cells (made up of cellulose), the presence of the cell wall is a common feature found in both prokaryotes and plant cells (Choice B).

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
Which statement provides evidence for the endosymbiotic theory?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Phospholipids readily form bilayers.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	Chloroplasts possess a double membrane.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	RNA is self-replicating.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Mitochondria possess a single membrane.
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. The smaller prokaryotes were engulfed via endocytosis, so they have their original membrane as well as the membrane of the larger prokaryote.  Choice B is correct.
Choice A is incorrect because it provides evidence for the evolution of plasma membranes not endosymbiotic theory. Choice C is incorrect because it provides evidence for the mechanism of inheritance. Choice D is incorrect because mitochondria have a double membrane.

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
Which part of the cell is labelled with the letter P?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8c50f434-e0ff-47b5-b17a-389a3e9bd2a2/images/aeaa4f06-2d32-4828-8370-65b4b9af9ffc/BI0395%20image.png)


[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia. (2016, March 1). Category: Electron Microscope Images. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved May 19, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscopy.jpg. Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Vacuole
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	Lysosome
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	Nucleoid
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	Nucleus
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is incorrect, as the photo shows an animal cell, which can contain smaller, single membraned vacuoles, but the nucleus is much larger. Choice B is incorrect as lysosomes are smaller and have a single membrane. Choice C is incorrect as nucleoids are only present in prokaryotes and are not membrane bound.

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
Which of the following supports the theory that multicellularity has evolved repeatedly?


- I.Sexual reproduction is more common in multicellular organisms, allowing for greater genetic diversity.II.Modern eukaryotes are believed to have evolved from larger prokaryotes which engulfed but didn't digest beneficial smaller prokaryotes.III.Fossil evidence indicates that different taxa developed multicellularity at different times in evolutionary history.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Fossils provide evidence that different taxa developed multicellularity at different times in evolutionary history, indicating that multicellularity developed independently in different taxa; Statement III is correct. Choice A is correct.
Although multicellular organisms more commonly reproduce sexually than single-celled organisms, leading to greater genetic diversity, this does not directly support the idea of multicellularity evolving repeatedly. It highlights one of the advantages of sexual reproduction, however, single-celled organisms tend to reproduce rapidly by asexual reproduction, which can lead to more effective dispersal and the withstanding of harsher conditions. Statement I is not true. Statement II  is not true as it summarises the theory of endosymbiosis rather than supports multicellularity evolving repeatedly. Choices B, C and D  are incorrect, as they all contain Statement II and/or Statement III.

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
What feature of chloroplasts provides evidence for the endosymbiotic theory?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ They have their own nucleus.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	They have a single membrane.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	They contain 70S ribosomes.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	 They contain a thylakoid membrane.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. The smaller prokaryotes contained their own 70S ribosomes which were distinct from the host cell's 80S ribosomes. Choice C is correct.
Choices A and  B are incorrect because chloroplasts do not have a nucleus and have a double membrane. Choice D  is incorrect because although chloroplasts do contain a thylakoid membrane, this is not evidence for the endosymbiotic theory.

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
Which of the following statements read true for differences between prokaryotes and eukaryotes?


- I.Prokaryotes have DNA associated with histones, while eukaryotic cells have naked DNA.II.Eukaryotes have linear chromosomes, while prokaryotes have circular chromosomes.III.Most prokaryotes have a singular chromosome, whilst most eukaryotic somatic cells contain at least two chromosomes.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Prokaryotes typically have DNA that is not associated with histones and is often referred to as ‘naked’. In eukaryotes, histone proteins help package the DNA into structural units called nucleosomes. This makes Statement I false.
Eukaryotic chromosomes are typically linear and located within the nucleus, while most prokaryotic organisms have a single circular chromosome found in a nucleoid region without a surrounding nuclear membrane. This makes Statement II true.
Most prokaryotes contain a single circular chromosome, while eukaryotic somatic cells are generally diploid with paired chromosomes. Therefore Statement III is true.
Seeming as only Statements II and III are true, this makes Choice B the correct answer to the question.
Choices A, C and D are all incorrect as they include Statement I.

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
Match the labelled structure (Q-T from the diagram) with its primary structure.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/38b38de6-6717-482a-9a4f-f546274b7e7d/images/ce1af51c-d72e-48f9-8b0a-39700a6e5d99/Ed2790.png)


[© Revision Village 2025. Created with BioRender.com]

Contains genetic informationProvides support and protectionRegulates the passage of substancesA.$\hspace{1em}$SQRB.$\hspace{1em}$TQSC.$\hspace{1em}$TQRD.$\hspace{1em}$TRQ
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
In the diagram, T indicates naked DNA, and this is the genetic material for the cell. Q indicates the cell wall, which provides structural support and protection. R indicates the cell membrane, which regulates the passage of substances in and out of the cell, and S indicates the cytoplasm, which is the site of metabolic reactions in the cell. Therefore, Choice C is the correct answer because it correctly matches the functions of the structures that are indicated by the letters in the diagram.
Choice A, Choice B, and Choice D do not correctly match the functions of the structures indicated by the letters in the diagram.

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
The electron micrograph below shows a cell of the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. Which of the labelled structures maintains the cell’s shape and protects the cell from lysing during osmosis?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/736cd18e-ee65-4f82-8af4-eb1a43c8be73/images/5dc39b3e-60d2-488c-8d82-06070c9413d6/BI0494.png)


[Source: Blokesch, M. & Schoolnik, G.K. (2007). Serogroup Conversion of Vibrio cholerae in Aquatic Reservoirs. PLoS Pathog 3(6): e81. Retrieved March 15, 2022, from https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.ppat.0030081.Copyright under CC BY 4.0]
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The cell membrane of prokaryotes is surrounded by a rigid cell wall. The cell wall provides shape and structure to the organism. It also prevents the cell from bursting when the cell takes up water through osmosis.  The cell wall is located between the cell membrane and the capsule, a sticky outer layer of polysaccharide. The cell wall is shown in the image below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/736cd18e-ee65-4f82-8af4-eb1a43c8be73/images/186347c3-bad0-4ecf-8cb6-3d8e5822df69/BI0494A.png)

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
Which of the following options correctly identifies the forms of DNA and the types of ribosomes found in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells?

Prokaryotic DNAEukaryotic DNAProkaryotic RibosomesEukaryotic RibosomesA.$\hspace{1em}$LinearCircular80S70SB.$\hspace{1em}$CircularLinear80S80SC.$\hspace{1em}$CircularLinear70S80SD.$\hspace{1em}$LinearLinear70S70S
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Prokaryotic cells have circular DNA and 70S ribosomes, while eukaryotic cells have linear DNA and 80S ribosomes. Therefore, Choice C is correct. Choices A, B and D are incorrect because they do not have the correct combinations.

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
Which process is most likely responsible for the origin of mitochondria as a eukaryotic cell organelle?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Osmosis
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Exocytosis
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Apoptosis
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Endocytosis
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A – Osmosis is an example of passive transport, which involves the movement of water across a semi-permeable membrane.
Choice B - Exocytosis is an example of active transport that moves large molecules out of the cell to the cell’s exterior.
Choice C – Apoptosis is the process of programmed cell death.
Choice D - Endocytosis is an example of active transport that moves large molecules, parts of a cell, or a cell from the cell’s exterior, into a cell’s interior. This is in accordance with the endosymbiotic theory, which is the most likely process by which mitochondria came to be eukaryotic organelles.

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
Which organelle is the site of protein synthesis?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a6800fc1-62df-4a80-8975-f59d30b437e0/images/4ddade12-66a0-4c52-9381-f4a372e51019/BI0398_A.png)

B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because it shows the rough endoplasmic reticulum, which has bound ribosomes that synthesise proteins.
Choice A shows the nucleus which contains the genetic information and controls the activity of the cell. Choice C shows a chloroplast, the site of photosynthesis. Choice D indicates the golgi apparatus which packages and transports proteins.

list.title: Question 38
list.content:
What feature distinguishes fungal hyphae and striated muscle from the two cell types shown in the images?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/aa05a687-8639-4d5b-b98e-676e515e3db9/images/cb9d1305-aecb-4b44-9d15-1ffb1d245817/bi0756.png)


[Source: Adapted from CNX OpenStax. (2016, May 27). File 04 00 00.jpg. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved March 5, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Figure_04_00_00.jpg Copyright under CC by 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ They are multinucleate.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ They only have one nucleus.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ They have unusually large cells that contain only one nucleus.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ They contain mitochondria.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Fungal hyphae and striated muscle are both exceptions to the cell theory as they are much larger than typical cells and are multinucleate. Choice B  is incorrect as the diagrams depict onion epidermis cells and mast cells, which each contain one nucleus. Choice C  is incorrect as both fungal hyphae and striated muscles contain multiple nuclei. Choice D is incorrect as fungal hyphae, striated muscle AND the cells in the diagram all contain mitochondria.

list.title: Question 39
list.content:
Which of the following correctly pairs the structure with the type of cell in which it is found?

StructureType of cellA.$\hspace{1em}$Nucleoid regionAnimalB.$\hspace{1em}$Cell wallProkaryoticC.$\hspace{1em}$ChloroplastFungal cellD.$\hspace{1em}$Sap vacuoleProkaryotic
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct because nearly all prokaryotic cells possess a cell wall that provides structure, support, and protection. Choice A is incorrect because a nucleoid region is characteristic of a prokaryotic cell, not an animal cell. Choice C is incorrect because chloroplasts are found in plants and some algae cells, but not fungi. Choice D is incorrect because sap vacuoles are characteristic of plant cells, not prokaryotic cells.

list.title: Question 40
list.content:
Which of the following rows correctly pairs the cell type with its nuclear characteristic?

Cell typeNuclear stateA.$\hspace{1em}$Phloem sieve tube elementsNo nucleusB.$\hspace{1em}$Skeletal muscle cellsSingle nucleusC.$\hspace{1em}$Red blood cellsSingle nucleusD.$\hspace{1em}$Aseptate fungal hyphaeNo nucleus
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because phloem sieve tube elements lose their nucleus as they mature to facilitate the transport of sugars. 
Choice B is incorrect because skeletal muscle cells are multinucleated to accommodate their length. 
Choice C is incorrect because mature red blood cells lack a nucleus. They jettison the nucleus when mature to increase the haemoglobin capacity of oxygen transport. 
Choice D is incorrect because aseptate fungal hyphae have a continuous cytoplasm containing many nuclei.

list.title: Question 41

Retrieved June 13, 2022, from https ://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Chloroplast_in_leaf_of_Anemone_sp_TEM_12000x.png Copyright free] - Label structures in the plant cell above: - using the letter R where starch can be found; [1] - using the letter S where lipids can be found; [1] - using the letter T where cellulose can be found. [1] - Compare and contrast between the structure and functions of glycogen and starch. [4]
list.markScheme: - - $\ce{ -> }$ arrow labelled R pointing to a lighter oval [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55c44e62-f294-437f-866e-7723a75ab94f/images/51c8aaf3-7ba5-402f-b12e-e626a9ec4fe8/450ai%201.png) - $\ce{ -> }$ arrow labelled S pointing to the cell membrane OR membrane around chloroplast OR thylakoid membrane OR lipid droplet OR vacuolar membrane [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55c44e62-f294-437f-866e-7723a75ab94f/images/fc427c88-70d0-4caa-9509-ff244ca0fd32/450aii.png) - $\ce{ -> }$ arrow labelled T pointing to the cell wall [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55c44e62-f294-437f-866e-7723a75ab94f/images/cc9f3445-e9f2-45b5-acd6-e04606b44b17/450aiii.png) - Any four of the following (should include AT LEAST ONE for compare and AT LEAST ONE for contrast): Compare: $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH are polysaccharides [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH are made up of $\alpha$- glucose molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH have 1,4 and 1,6 linkages [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH are energy storage molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH amylopectin in starch and glycogen are branched molecules [1] Contrast: $\ce{ -> }$ glycogen is more branched IN CONTRAST TO starch, OR amylose of starch is unbranched, amylopectin has few branched chains WHEREAS glycogen is more branched [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Starch is composed of two different polymers, amylose and amylopectin WHEREAS glycogen is composed of only one polymer [1] $\ce{ -> }$ starch is found in plant cells WHEREAS glycogen is found in animal cells [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Both starch and glycogen are polysaccharides ($\checkmark$) made of $\alpha$- glucose molecules ($\checkmark$), which have 1,4 and 1,6 linkages ($\checkmark$). Starch is composed of two different polymers; amylose (unbranched and forms a helix) and amylopectin (branched), whereas glycogen is composed of only one type of polymer ($\checkmark$). Both amylopectin, in starch, and glycogen are branched molecules ($\checkmark$), but glycogen is more branched than starch ($\checkmark$). Both are energy storage ($\checkmark$)molecules but starch is found in plant cells whereas glycogen is found in animal cells ($\checkmark$). $\underline{\textrm{For additional detail}}$: , see 4:30 in Carbohydrates Key Concept Video: https://www.revisionvillage.com/ib-biology/sl/key-concepts/?keyConceptId=4fa07df3-4cd4-4a65-897b-96212f2186ee

(2022, June 13). Synechococcus elongates. Wikipedia. Retrieved June 19, 2022, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synechococcus_elongatus Copyright under CC BY 3.0] - - State whether the cell shown in the photomicrograph is eukaryotic or prokaryotic. Give a reason for your answer. [2] - State two features found in both eukaryotic and prokaryotic cell structures. [2] - Identify the type of microscope which was used to produce the microphotograph above. Give a reason for your answer. [2] - Describe the function of X. [2] - Compare and contrast the structure of the Golgi apparatus and rough endoplasmic reticulum. [2]
list.markScheme: - - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ (cell is) prokaryotic OR is a prokaryote [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (because it) does not have a nucleus OR has nucleoid OR no membrane-bound organelles OR a named organelle such as a Golgi apparatus, rough endoplasmic reticulum or mitochondria [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: The cell is prokaryotic ($\checkmark$) because it doesn’t have a nucleus ($\checkmark$) or membrane bound organelles. - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ both have a plasma membrane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both have free ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both eukaryotic plant cells and prokaryotes have cell walls [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both have cytoplasm [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells both have a plasma membrane ($\checkmark$) and free ribosomes ($\checkmark$). - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ electron microscope [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (because it has) higher resolution OR ultrastructure OR internal structure of the cell is visible [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: It is an electron microscope ($\checkmark$), as the image is at a high resolution ($\checkmark$) where you can clearly see the ultrastructure of the cell. - Both of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ (X is the) nucleoid region OR poly-phosphate body [1] $\ce{ -> }$ contains DNA OR the genetic information of the cell OR controls the activities of the cell OR contains phosphates needed for DNA synthesis [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: X is the nucleoid region ($\checkmark$), it contains the cell’s DNA ($\checkmark$). - Any two of the following: One difference and one similarity are needed for full marks $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH consist of flattened membrane areas [1] $\ce{ -> }$ rough endoplasmic reticulum has ribosomes bound to it WHEREAS the Golgi apparatus doesn’t [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Golgi apparatus has shorter cisternae THAN rough endoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ part of the rough endoplasmic reticulum is continuous with the nuclear membrane WHEREAS the Golgi apparatus is not [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: The Golgi apparatus and rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) are both made up of flattened membrane areas ($\checkmark$), however the RER has ribosomes bound to the outside of it, whereas the Golgi apparatus does not ($\checkmark$). Also, the Golgi apparatus has shorter cisternae ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 43
list.content: Below is a diagram of a motor neuron. Neurons are the longest cells in the human body. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7876a55e-0692-459c-a884-5c8979a6dd42/images/827ddc07-1d3d-43d2-a23e-f8f707d37a6c/BI0833A.png) [©Revision Village 2023. Created with BioRender.com] - Explain the factors that limit cell size in humans. [4] Below is a diagram of a Paramecium, a unicellular organism. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7876a55e-0692-459c-a884-5c8979a6dd42/images/971509ed-990a-4f10-96a2-6c8d5a7a22a1/paramecium%20black.png) [©Revision Village 2023] - Explain how life functions are performed by Paramecium. [4]
list.markScheme: - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ surface area affects the rate at which materials enter and leave the cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ volume affects the rate at which materials are used and produced by the cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the surface area to volume ratio affects the rate of metabolism in a cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the bigger the cell, the smaller the SA ratio is [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cells having a low SA ratio cannot exchange materials fast enough [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some cells, OR motor neurons, OR muscle cells, OR other named example in humans, are long and thin, which maintains a high SA ratio [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: The surface area of a cell affects the rate at which materials enter and leave cells ($\checkmark$). On the other hand, the cell’s volume affects the rate at which materials are used and produced ($\checkmark$). A small surface area to volume ratio is not ideal for human cells because it limits the cell’s ability to export waste from the cytoplasm rapidly enough to meet the cytoplasm’s metabolic needs, such as the availability of oxygen ($\checkmark$). A large cell has a small surface area to volume ratio ($\checkmark$). Therefore, the transport of the substances is more efficient in small cells. - Any four of the following (function of life must be mentioned when explaining how Paramecium performs this, to award mark): $\ce{ -> }$ functions of life are metabolism AND growth AND reproduction AND nutrition AND homeostasis AND movement AND excretion AND response to stimuli, OR sensitivity [1] $\ce{ -> }$ movement in Paramecium is demonstrated by cilia used to propel themselves through water [1] $\ce{ -> }$ response is through reacting to stimuli in the environment OR avoidance of light [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homeostasis is demonstrated by keeping the internal conditions within set limits OR excess water is expelled by the contractile vacuole [1] $\ce{ -> }$ metabolism is carried out by enzymes in the cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ growth is an irreversible increase in size OR dry mass and paramecium achieve this through accumulating organic matter OR nutrients from food [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reproduction function in Paramecium is demonstrated by asexual division through binary fission, OR mitosis or micronucleus and amitotic division of macronucleus OR sexually through conjugation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ excretion is the removal of metabolic waste products from the cell OR diffusion of CO2 out of the cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nutrition is performed by ingesting smaller organisms and digesting them in vesicles OR through endocytosis [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Paramecium acquires nutrients by ingesting bacteria and digesting them in vesicles($\checkmark$). It exhibits growth when it irreversibly increases in size by accumulating organic matter from ingested food ($\checkmark$). Paramecium responds to different environmental stimuli. For example, it changes the direction of its movement once it touches a solid object ($\checkmark$). Excretion in Paramecium occurs when waste products such as carbon dioxide diffuse out of the cell ($\checkmark$). Paramecium reproduces both asexually by binary fission ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 44
list.content:
What do the two labelled organelles have in common?

- B. $\hspace{1em}$	They contain cristae
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	They are surrounded by a double membrane
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	They contain starch grains

C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
X is pointing to the nucleus and Y is pointing to a mitochondrion. Choice A is incorrect as neither organelle has a single membrane. Choice B is incorrect as only mitochondria contain cristae, the nucleus does not. Choice D is incorrect as neither the nucleus or mitochondria contain starch grains.

list.content: The electron micrograph shows a eukaryotic cell. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/933ce724-12f2-4bfc-adca-7b858d9b5e3a/images/c44d1736-95cd-481f-b229-0bead3bac4bb/424a.png) [Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia. Copyright under CC-SA 3.0] - - State the name of an organelle visible in the electron micrograph that provides structural evidence for the endosymbiotic theory. [3] - Contrast the structure of a mitochondrion and typical prokaryote. [2]
list.markScheme: - - $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR mitochondrion [1] [1 mark maximum] - $\ce{ -> }$ any mitochondrion labelled correctly with the letter S (mitochondria are the darker grey oval structures in the cytoplasm) [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/933ce724-12f2-4bfc-adca-7b858d9b5e3a/images/8caebdd2-0a5e-414e-b235-c89e98e0ec57/424b.png) [Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia. (2016, March 1). Category: Electron Microscope Images. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved May 19, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscopy.jpg. Copyright under CC-SA 3.0] - any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ has a double membrane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ contains its own genes OR contains circular DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ contains (70S) ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ can carry out transcription OR translation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ can self replicate [1] [3 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: The mitochondrion has a double membrane ($\checkmark$) as it has evolved from a prokaryote that acquired a second membrane when it was engulfed by a larger prokaryote. It also contains circular DNA ($\checkmark$) and 70S ribosomes ($\checkmark$). - any two of the following (the answer can be in a table format): $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria have a double membrane BUT prokaryotes have a single membrane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria lack a cell wall BUT prokaryotes have a cell wall t [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria have cristae BUT prokaryotes do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotes may have flagella OR pili BUT mitochondria do noto [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Mitochondria have a double membrane whereas prokaryotes do not. ($\checkmark$). Some prokaryotes have flagella, but mitochondria do not ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 46
list.content:
Which statements about unicellular and multicellular organisms are correct?

Unicellular organismsMulticellular organismsA.$\hspace{1em}$They only reproduce asexuallyContains differentiated cellsB.$\hspace{1em}$Consist of only one cellAll cellular processes are carried out by one organelleC.$\hspace{1em}$Can reproduce sexuallyThey have emergent propertiesD.$\hspace{1em}$Contains differentiated cellsCan reproduce sexually
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A  is incorrect, as not all unicellular organisms reproduce asexually. Choice B is incorrect, as both unicellular and multicellular organisms contain multiple organelles that carry out different functions. Choice D  is incorrect, because unicellular organisms do not contain more than one cell, and so do not contain multiple differentiated cells.

list.title: Question 47
list.content:
The micrograph shows the ultrastructure of a cell. What type of cell is shown and what process is it undergoing?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fea1bf52-eec5-4eec-b5ea-8f2d8a25bff5/images/418a09cc-3e55-4c17-b147-d0dfe66c6d9a/BI1471%20fig1.png)


[Source: Adapted from Lewis, M. E., Belland, R. J., AbdelRahman, Y. M., Beatty, W. L., Aiyar, A. A., Zea, A. H., Greene, S. J., Marrero, L., Buckner, L. R., Tate, D. J., McGowin, C. L., Kozlowski, P. A., O’Brien, M., Lillis, R. A., Martin, D. H., & Quayle, A. J. (2014, May 15). Morphologic and molecular evaluation of chlamydia trachomatis growth in human endocervix reveals distinct growth patterns. Frontiers. Retrieved February 11 , 2024, from https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fcimb.2014.00071/full. Copyright free]

$\hspace{1em}$Type of cell  Process A.$\hspace{1em}$EukaryoticMitosisB.$\hspace{1em}$EukaryoticBinary fissionC.ProkaryoticMitosisD.ProkaryoticBinary fission
list.markScheme:
D
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
Prokaryotic cells have an approximate diameter of 0.1$-$ 5.0  µm, whereas eukaryotic cells are significantly larger with a diameter range of 10 $-$ 100  µm.  The cells in the micrograph have an approximate diameter of 0.5  µm, so are prokaryotic. Prokaryotic cells do not replicate themselves using mitosis, they use binary fission. Choice D  is correct.
Choices A  and B are incorrect as the cells in the micrograph are prokaryotic, not eukaryotic. Choice C  is incorrect as prokaryotic cells lack a mitotic spindle, so do not carry out mitosis, they carry out binary fission.

list.title: Question 48
list.content: The diagram shows a human joint. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/05754fea-41d1-4915-aad1-882ade1c9e5b/images/47ad4795-c336-4258-9347-c1de2fb18e34/BI1408.png) [© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com] - - Label the cartilage with the letter X. [1] - State the name and role of the fluid found within this type of joint. [1] - State one way in which skeletal muscle fibres are exceptions to the cell theory. [1] - The contractile proteins actin and myosin in skeletal muscle fibres bring about movement of this joint. Explain how two other proteins within these cells, along with calcium, control the contraction of skeletal muscle. [3]
list.markScheme: - - $\ce{ -> }$ cartilage must be labelled with an X at the end of either bone [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/05754fea-41d1-4915-aad1-882ade1c9e5b/images/8846f3ce-713c-4b53-aedc-4aebff966c5e/BI1408AnsA.png) [© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com] - - $\ce{ -> }$ synovial fluid AND lubricates the joints OR prevents friction between bones [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The fluid within this type of joint is called synovial fluid and it lubricates the joint ($\checkmark$). - Any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ multinucleated [1] $\ce{ -> }$ much larger OR longer than most cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ formed through fusion of multiple cells [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: They are multinucleated ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ tropomyosin winds around actin, covering myosin-binding sites OR tropomyosin covers binding sites on actin [1] $\ce{ -> }$ troponin bound to tropomyosin helps maintain position of tropomyosin on actin filament [1] $\ce{ -> }$ action potential OR stimulation of muscle fibre by nerve impulse causes calcium ions to be released from sarcoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ calcium ions bind to troponin, causing it to change shape OR bringing about conformational change [1] $\ce{ -> }$ troponin bound to calcium ions moves tropomyosin away from myosin-binding sites allowing myosin to bind to actin [1] $\ce{ -> }$ when no stimulation of muscle fibre OR no action potential along sarcoplasm, calcium ions are actively pumped back into sarcoplasmic reticulum [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The protein tropomyosin is coiled around actin filaments, covering the myosin-binding sites ($\checkmark$), and thereby preventing myosin forming cross bridges with the actin. Upon the arrival of an action potential, calcium ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum ($\checkmark$). These calcium ions then bind to troponin, a protein associated with both actin and tropomyosin, (($\checkmark$). The binding of calcium ions to troponin induces a conformational change ($\checkmark$) in the protein, which in turn causes tropomyosin to shift away from myosin-binding sites. Consequently, the myosin heads are now free to bind to actin ($\checkmark$), enabling muscle contraction to occur.

list.title: Question 49
list.content: - Distinguish between a colony of algal cells forming a multicellular sphere, and a multicellular plant such as a water lily. [3] - Draw a labelled diagram which shows the structure of an animal cell. [5] - Describe the evidence for the endosymbiotic theory. [7]
list.markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ colony of algal cells are generally undifferentiated WHEREAS multicellular plants like water lilies are composed of different types OR differentiated of cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ no OR minimal organisation OR minimal division of labour of cells in algal colony, WHEREAS in multicellular plant cells arranged into tissues, organs and organ systems, OR well-defined structures carry out specific roles in plants [1] $\ce{ -> }$ each individual algal cell is capable of performing all necessary functions for life OR survival independently WHEREAS most individual cells of multicellular plants cannot survive independently OR away from the main body of the plant [1] $\ce{ -> }$ each algal cell in a colony is genetically distinct, WHEREAS nearly all cells in a multicellular organism are genetically identical [1] $\ce{ -> }$ development of colonies is often simple OR cells simply join existing colony WHEREAS plants undergo complex developmental processes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ reproduction in an algal colony typically involves asexual methods WHEREAS in multicellular plants such as the water lily typically involves sexual reproduction OR multicellular plants use both sexual and asexual reproduction [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Unlike true multicellular organisms like water lilies, algal colonies lack cellular differentiation and specialised tissues. Individual cells within the colony are genetically distinct and largely independent, being able to perform all vital functions. In contrast, most cells in the multicellular plant are genetically identical ($\checkmark$) and usually do not survive when separated from the plant ($\checkmark$). These cells become specialised ($\checkmark$) and form tissues, organs, and organ systems within the plant. This intricate division of labour ($\checkmark$) allows plants to achieve greater size and complexity. - Any four of the following labelled correctly in an appropriate drawing of an animal cell: $\ce{ -> }$ nucleus (shown with double membrane) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cell OR plasma membrane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondrion [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ribosome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ golgi apparatus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ rough endoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ smooth endoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ lysosome [1] and the following: $\ce{ -> }$ diagram drawn without sketchy lines and acceptable size [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1ff31851-24a7-4efc-b3a3-080da5df9c59/images/efb7b494-b22f-41fc-8c24-c635f2f9bcac/BI1050.png) [© Revision Village 2022] - Any seven of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ larger prokaryotes OR cells engulfed smaller prokaryotes OR cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ingested cell was kept alive [1] $\ce{ -> }$ symbiotic relationship between both cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ingested cell acquired a second membrane [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ingested cell is ancestor of chloroplasts OR mitochondria [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplast OR mitochondrial structures provide evidence for the endosymbiotic theory [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria contain 70S ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria contain their own DNA OR looped DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria can conduct transcription OR translation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria divide in a similar manner to prokaryotic cells OR by binary fission [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chloroplasts OR mitochondria are similar in size to prokaryotes [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The endosymbiotic theory explains the origin of some structures in eukaryotic cells, including chloroplasts and mitochondria. The ancestors of chloroplasts and mitochondria were prokaryotes that were engulfed by larger prokaryotes ($\checkmark$). The ingested cells were kept alive ($\checkmark$) and both cells eventually developed a symbiotic relationship ($\checkmark$) with the cell that engulfed them. When the larger cells engulfed the smaller cells, the smaller cells gained a second membrane ($\checkmark$) as they were engulfed via endocytosis. Further evidence for the theory is that chloroplasts and mitochondria contain their own 70s ribosomes ($\checkmark$) so can make their own proteins, and also contain their own DNA ($\checkmark$) so can carry out transcription ($\checkmark$). Chloroplasts and mitochondria are also able to divide in a similar manner to prokaryotic cells ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 50
list.content:
The following electron micrograph shows part of an exocrine pancreas cell. Which of the labelled structures is responsible for the production of vesicles for exocytosis?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2f272307-8afa-40f2-baa3-3849afb23e89/images/ec933293-9b93-43e7-a9a2-a31402bd84cb/BI0532.png)


[Source: Adapted from Howard, L.  (n.d.). File: Pancreatic cells - TEM.jpg. Wikipedia.  Retrieved January, 3, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Pancreatic_cells_-_TEM.jpg. Copyright under Public Domain]
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The Golgi apparatus produces vesicles that contain substances destined for exocytosis from the cell. The Golgi apparatus is composed of stacks of flattened pouches called cisternae. These appear in a micrograph as the stacked, flattened discs indicated by Choice C.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2f272307-8afa-40f2-baa3-3849afb23e89/images/72bfb0b1-4b14-4045-980a-bd0565c72938/BI0532A.png)


[Source: Adapted from Howard, L.  (n.d.). File: Pancreatic cells - TEM.jpg. Wikipedia.  Retrieved January, 3, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Pancreatic_cells_-_TEM.jpg. Copyright under Public Domain]
Choice A is the plasma membrane, Choice B is a lysosome and Choice D is the nucleus.

list.title: Question 51
list.content: All organisms contain genetic material. The type, quantity and location of genetic material differ between kingdoms and species. - State if the cell shown in the image is a prokaryotic or eukaryotic cell. Give a reason for your answer. [1] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8024806a-71b0-45c1-abd9-26abe1b9d775/images/4acbd2c2-a08b-4399-bb2b-e8c3deecb828/BI0199.png) [Source: Adapted from Ruiz (16th January 2007). File: Prokaryote cell diagram international.svg. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved 18th May 2022 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Prokaryote_cell_diagram_international.svg. Copyright-free] - Distinguish between prokaryotic and eukaryotic DNA. [2]
list.markScheme: - The following: $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cell BECAUSE chromosome is looped OR no nucleus is present [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: This is a prokaryotic($\checkmark$) cell because the chromosome is not within a nucleus($\checkmark$). - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic DNA is looped, BUT the majority of eukaryotic DNA is linear [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic DNA is not contained in a nucleus, BUT the majority of eukaryotic DNA is found within a nucleus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic DNA is found in a chromosome and plasmids WHEREAS the majority of eukaryotic DNA is found in chromosomes and not in plasmids [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the majority of eukaryotic DNA is always associated with proteins (histones) WHILE prokaryotic DNA is not bound to proteins (with the exception of Archae whose DNA is associated with proteins) [1] [2 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Prokaryotic DNA is looped while the majority of eukaryotic DNA is linear($\checkmark$). DNA can be found in plasmids in some prokaryotes($\checkmark$), while the only plasmids found in eukaryotes are present in mitochondria and chloroplasts.

list.title: Question 52
list.content:
Which statements about chloroplasts and mitochondria support the endosymbiotic theory?

ChloroplastsMitochondria$\hspace{1em}$A.$\hspace{1em}$Contain 70S ribosomesContain cristae$\hspace{1em}$B.$\hspace{1em}$Found in prokaryotesContain 80S ribosomes$\hspace{1em}$C.$\hspace{1em}$Have a single membraneContain circular DNA$\hspace{1em}$D.$\hspace{1em}$Contain 70S ribosomesHave a double membrane
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The endosymbiotic theory states that larger prokaryotes engulfed smaller prokaryotes, which were the ancestors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. The smaller prokaryotes were engulfed via endocytosis, so they have their original membrane as well as the membrane of the larger prokaryote.   Both chloroplasts and mitochondria have 70S ribosomes and a double membrane. Choice D is correct.
Choice A is incorrect because the fact that mitochondria contain cristae is not due to the endosymbiotic theory. Choice B  is incorrect because chloroplasts are not found in prokaryotes. Choice C  is incorrect because chloroplasts have a double membrane.

list.title: Question 53
list.content: - Outline the steps in calculating the magnification of a micrograph. [4] - Describe the steps taken to focus on a specimen using the 40x objective lens of a light microscope. [4]
list.markScheme: - Any four of the following: $\ce{->}$ measure (using a ruler) the scale bar on the drawing OR micrograph [1] $\ce{->}$ note the stated length which the scale bar represents [1] $\ce{->}$ convert the represented and real length or scale bar into the same units [1] $\ce{->}$ M= I/A OR any correct example of the calculation [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: To calculate the magnification of a microphotograph, the first step is to measure the scale bar using a ruler ($\checkmark$). The second step is to note the length the scale bar represents ($\checkmark$). This gives you the actual size of the image. These two measurements should be converted to the same units ($\checkmark$). The last step is to divide the length measured by the ruler by the length represented by the scale bar ($\checkmark$). During this calculation, units cancel out. Therefore, the magnification does not have units. - Any four of the following: $\ce{->}$ use the lowest power OR 4X objective lens first [1] $\ce{->}$ place the specimen OR slide directly below the objective lens OR on the centre of the microscope stage [1] $\ce{->}$ turn the coarse focus knob to focus on the specimen at 4X [1] $\ce{->}$ adjust the turret OR change the objective lens so the medium power OR 10X objective lens is used [1] $\ce{->}$ refocus on the specimen using a fine focus knob at 10X and 40X [1] $\ce{->}$ adjust the turret OR change the objective lens, so the high power OR 40X objective lens is used [1] $\ce{->}$ while fine focusing always move the lens away from the slide [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Place the specimen in the centre of the microscope stage ($\checkmark$). Use the 4x objective lens first ($\checkmark$) and use the coarse focus knob ($\checkmark$) to focus on the specimen. Adjust the position of the specimen so it is in the middle of the field of view and then switch to the 10x ($\checkmark$) objective lens and refocus using the fine focus knob, ($\checkmark$) by moving lens away from the specimen ($\checkmark$) to prevent lens breakage. Finally, switch to the 40x objective lens ($\checkmark$) and use the fine focus knob to refocus on the specimen.

list.title: Question 54
list.content: The micrograph below shows Cyanobacteria, which contain chlorophyll. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c3dfa29a-d486-40b4-9fc1-d44b66ce3fc7/images/937853fc-bf32-495b-aba7-33e0cf82a199/BI1197-SL.png) [Source: Adapted from Thompson L. and Whatson N. (2007, January 1). Cyanobacteria. Wikipedia. Retrieved on September 6, 2023, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyanobacteria#. Copyright under CCO] - Using your knowledge and the micrograph, state two features that would indicate that this is a bacterium. [2] - Outline the structural differences between animal and plant cells. [3] - Explain how light energy is used in photosynthesis to carry out anabolic reactions. [3]
list.markScheme: - Any two of the following $\ce{ -> }$ cell wall of peptidoglycan [1] $\ce{ -> }$ naked DNA OR DNA not associated with histones OR proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nucleoid OR DNA free in cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ no membrane bound organelles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 70s ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ cell smaller than 10μm [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Two features that would indicate that this is a bacterium are it has no membrane-bound organelles ($\checkmark$) and 70s ribosomes ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ plant cells have a cell wall, WHEREAS animal cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ plant cells generally have a central vacuole WHEREAS animal cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ plant cells have chloroplasts WHEREAS animal cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ animal cells may have lysosomes WHEREAS plant cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ animal cells may have cilia OR flagella WHEREAS plant cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ animal cells have centrioles WHEREAS plant cells do not [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Plant cells have a cell wall, central vacuole and chloroplasts, whereas animal cells do not ($\checkmark$) ($\checkmark$) ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ light energy is absorbed by chlorophyll [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light energy is transferred to electrons OR is used to excite electrons [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light energy splitting water molecules OR photolysis releases electrons for the electron transport chain OR hydrogen ions for use in ATP production [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light energy is used to synthesise ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate OR NADPH from electrons and one proton [1] $\ce{ -> }$ NADPH OR ATP is used to make larger organic compounds OR glucose OR starch OR other named organic compound from carbon dioxide [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Light energy is absorbed by chlorophyll ($\checkmark$) and is used to excite electrons ($\checkmark$). These electrons reduce NADP+ to form NADPH, which is an anabolic reaction ($\checkmark$). Energy present in NADPH is then used to produce glucose from carbon dioxide ($\checkmark$). This is also an anabolic reaction.

list.title: Question 55
list.content:
The diagram shows three dividing eukaryotic cells (not drawn to scale).
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d44418d9-eb6c-4a6b-9968-42a3f6f183f2/images/57370bbe-8a79-4a6c-a4b4-6083ac8eae6f/BI2852%20A2.2%20core%20MCQ.jpeg.JPEG)


[© Revision Village 2025. Created in BioRender.com]

Which row correctly pairs each cell with its type?

Cell XCell YCell ZA.$\hspace{1em}$Palisade mesophyllYeastLiverB.$\hspace{1em}$LiverPalisade mesophyllYeastC.$\hspace{1em}$YeastLiverPalisade mesophyllD.$\hspace{1em}$Palisade mesophyllLiverYeast
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Cell X is undergoing budding, a process characteristic of unicellular fungi like yeast. The cell also has a cell wall, a large vacuole and no chloroplasts, reinforcing that this cell is indeed a fungal cell, such as yeast.
Cell Y has no cell wall, no visible vacuoles and there are centrioles in the dividing cells, indicating that this is a dividing animal cell, such as a liver cell.
Cell Z has is dividing into daughter cells, each of which has a cell wall, vacuole, and chloroplasts. The cell is also dividing evenly by laying down a cell plate between the cells, which will develop into the cell walls of the new cells. These are all features of plant cells, such as palisade mesophyll cells.
Choice C is therefore the correct answer to this question.

list.title: Question 56
list.content:
The figure below shows the results of a study on the evolution of multicellularity. Obligate multicellularity means the organism is always multicellular, facultative multicellularity means the organism is usually unicellular but can sometimes form multicellular structures.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e940829b-1b89-44cf-8a66-34d55df8cf92/images/6b245b5b-8c5e-4ec0-ad11-47b0515ebe5a/Ed2727.png)


[Source: Adapted from Fisher, R. (2013). Group Formation, Relatedness, and the Evolution of Multicellularity. Current Biology, 23. Retrieved April 2025  from https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960982213005678. CC BY 3.0.]

What can be deduced from this phylogenetic tree?


- I.All mammals are obligately multicellularII.Multicellularity evolved once in eukaryotesIII.All prokaryotes are unicellular




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is true because mammals are animals, and from the phylogenetic tree, the word animals is boxed(obligately multicellular). 
Statement II is false because multicellularity appears on multiple separate branches that do not share a recent common ancestor, suggesting independent evolution. 
Statement III is false because cyanobacteria are prokaryotes, and the tree shows them boxed, indicating they are multicellular. 
Therefore, Choice A is correct as it only contains the one true Statement I.
Choices B, C, and D are all incorrect as they include one or more of the false Statements II and III.

list.title: Question 57

(2022, June 13). Synechococcus elongatus. Wikipedia.
