list.title: Question 58
list.content:
The table below compares two specialised cells found in the human body:
Cell TypePrimary FunctionProteins ExpressedSkeletal MuscleMovementActin & MyosinNeuronCommunicationNeurotransmitters & Ion Channel Proteins
Which of the following explains the differences between the specialised cells?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Muscle cells and neurons have different DNA, so they produce different proteins
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Each cell type expresses only the genes needed for its function
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Differentiation permanently deletes unused genes from a cell’s DNA
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Neurons and muscle cells switch functions over time, depending on environmental conditions
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct. Each cell type expresses only the genes needed for its function, while other genes remain inactive. This selective gene expression leads to structural and functional differences between cells.
Choice A is incorrect. All cells in an organism (except gametes and red blood cells) contain the same DNA. Differences in protein production result from differences in gene expression, not in DNA sequence. Choice C is incorrect. Differentiation silences genes but does not remove them. Choice D is incorrect. Once differentiated, cells do not differentiate again — a neuron will not become a muscle cell later in life.

list.title: Question 59
list.content:
Which statement(s) provide evidence for the endosymbiotic theory?



- I. $\hspace{1.6em}$ Mitochondria and chloroplasts have adaptations that increase their surface area
- II. $\hspace{1.3em}$ Mitochondria and chloroplasts can make ATP
- III. $\hspace{1em}$ Mitochondria and chloroplasts have their own ribosomes




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
B
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
The endosymbiotic theory explains that modern eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells, when larger prokaryotes engulfed, but did not digest, other prokaryotes that are the precursors of modern chloroplasts and mitochondria. Evidence for this includes mitochondria and chloroplasts being the only organelles in eukaryotes that have their own ribosomes (Statement III). Choice B  is correct.
Statement I  is incorrect as the adaptations that increase the surface area of mitochondria and chloroplasts are not evidence for endosymbiosis. Statement II  is incorrect as before they were engulfed, the ancient prokaryotic precursors to mitochondria and chloroplasts had the ability to generate ATP, so this ability was not acquired as a result of endosymbiosis. Choices A, C and D are incorrect as they contain Statements I and/or II.

Name one hormone produced by the pancreas and state what the stimulus is for its secretion. [1]

Copyright by CC 4.0] - any two of the following (must have structure and function to gain mark): $\ce{ -> }$ extensive endoplasmic reticulum to synthesise enzymes OR proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ many mitochondria to produce ATP for protein synthesis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ many secretory vesicles to secrete substances [1] $\ce{ -> }$ many Golgi apparatus to process and package proteins [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The exocrine cell has an extensive endoplasmic reticulum that synthesises enzymes ($\checkmark$) and many mitochondria that produce ATP for protein synthesis ($\checkmark$). - any one of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ insulin secreted in response to high OR increase in blood glucose OR sugar levels [1] $\ce{ -> }$ glucagon secreted in response to low OR decrease in blood glucose OR sugar levels [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The pancreas secretes insulin in response to an increase in blood glucose levels ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 61
list.content:
The plasma membrane, a structure common to all cells, is primarily composed of a phospholipid bilayer. What is the fundamental reason for this specific lipid arrangement?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ To provide a flexible boundary for the cell and a source of stored energy.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ To create a rigid barrier impermeable to most substances for protection.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ To form a selectively permeable barrier due to the hydrophobic nature of the lipids.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ To actively transport molecules using energy from the lipids.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because it accurately describes the plasma membrane as selectively permeable, allowing some things to pass and some not, and this is because the tails of the phospholipids comprising the membrane are hydrophobic.
Choice A is incorrect. While it’s true that the membrane provides a flexible boundary for the cell, it is not a source of energy. If the membrane is broken down to release energy, the boundary of the cell will be destroyed, and the cell will cease to exist.
Choice B is incorrect because the membrane is not rigid or impermeable. It is flexible and partially permeable.
Choice D is incorrect because the energy used to transport molecules across the membrane is typically provided by the hydrolysis of ATP.

list.title: Question 62
list.content:
The diagram shows two kinds of specialised cells found in the same individual.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/df8e8502-1eca-482c-9133-b157a8e47ce1/images/6ad214c5-d6f9-4452-93c7-7dc8ad775d97/BI1556.png)


[© Revision Village 2024. Created with BioRender.com]

Which of the following statements would be true for both cell types?


- I.They share the same genome.II.They develop based on the expression of some genes and not others.III.They develop from the same stem cell populations.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because both cells contain the same genes/genome in their diploid nucleus (Statement I). They differentiate or become specialised during their development due to the expression of some genes but not others (Statement II).
Statement III is not true because although both types of cells originate from stem cells, they come from different lineages and therefore develop from different stem cell populations or niches. Choices B, C, and D are incorrect because they contain Statement III.

list.title: Question 63
list.content: - Outline the different uses of karyograms. [3] - Distinguish between cells with haploid and diploid nuclei. [4] - Compare and contrast different types of chromosomes. [8]
list.markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms are images of the chromosomes in an organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length OR Sex chromosomes are the 23rd pair in human karyograms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to identify the sex of an individual [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy, e.g. Down syndrome OR Patau syndrome OR Klinefelter syndrome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to determine if a chromosome is missing OR if part of a chromosome is missing [1] [3 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Karyograms ($\checkmark$) are images of the chromosomes in an organism. In a karyogram, the pairs of homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length ($\checkmark$). The sex chromosomes are shown as the 23rd pair in human karyograms. Karyograms can be used to determine if an individual is a biological male or female ($\checkmark$). Two X chromosomes are present in a human female cell, and one X chromosome and one Y chromosome are present in a human male cell. Karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy (three copies of a chromosome) e.g. Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, Edward’s syndrome and Klinefelter syndrome). - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes, OR one chromosome per type WHEREAS diploid nuclei have two sets OR two chromosomes of each type [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei have one allele for each gene WHEREAS diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei in humans have 23 chromosomes, and diploid nuclei in humans have 46 chromosomes OR any other valid species example [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid cells are usually gametes WHEREAS diploid cells are usually somatic cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid cells are usually the result of meiosis, WHILE diploid cells are usually the result of mitosis. [1] [4 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes($\checkmark$), whereas diploid nuclei have two sets of chromosomes. For example, in humans($\checkmark$), gametes have 23 chromosomes, while somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Haploid nuclei have one allele for each gene, ($\checkmark$) whereas diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene. In humans, only gametes($\checkmark$) have haploid nuclei, whereas the rest of the somatic cells have diploid nuclei. - Any eight of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes are composed of DNA molecules with different lengths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes have different numbers of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes have different types OR different numbers of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both prokaryotic AND eukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, WHILE eukaryotic and archaeal chromosomes are associated with proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic chromosomes are looped molecules of DNA, WHILE eukaryotic chromosomes are linear molecules of DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH autosomes and sex chromosomes contain genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the human Y chromosome carries information mainly coding for male sex determination and development, WHILE the X chromosome carries information for other body characteristics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there is only one pair of sex chromosomes, WHILE there can be more than one pair of autosomes (in different species) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ autosomes are pairs of homologous chromosomes of equal length, WHILE two sex chromosomes can be different lengths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chromosomes can be homologous and non-homologous [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes of equal length carrying the same genes, but different alleles, WHILE non-homologous chromosomes, carry different genes [1] [8 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: All chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes, but they differ in length ($\checkmark$) and in the number of genes ($\checkmark$) and type of genes ($\checkmark$). Similarities and differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA ($\checkmark$). Bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, but eukaryotic chromosomes are associated with proteins ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic chromosomes are looped, while eukaryotic chromosomes are linear ($\checkmark$). Similarities and differences between autosomes and sex chromosomes: Both autosomes and sex chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes. Autosomes are chromosomes that do not determine sex and do not have genes for sex-linked characteristics; sex chromosomes determine sex and have genes for sex-linked traits. There is one pair of sex chromosomes in a somatic nucleus, but there can be more than one pair of autosomes ($\checkmark$) in a somatic nucleus. X and Y chromosomes are of different lengths, while autosomal homologous chromosome pairs are equal in length ($\checkmark$) Comparing non-homologous chromosomes and homologous chromosomes: Homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes that have genes for the same characteristics and can have the same or different alleles. Non-homologous chromosomes have genes for different characteristics ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 64
list.content:
The table below presents observations made about four newly discovered entities (W, X, Y and Z).
EntityObservationWContains a cell wall, cytoplasm, and genetic material, but no internal compartments.XConsists of a protein coat surrounding RNA.YContains membrane-bound compartments, each containing DNA.ZExists as free-floating DNA molecules in a liquid medium.

Based on cell theory, which row of the table below correctly identifies whether each entity is likely to be classified as a living organism?
Entity WEntity XEntity YEntity ZA.$\hspace{1em}$YesNoYesNoB.$\hspace{1em}$NoYesNoYesC.$\hspace{1em}$YesNoNoYesD.$\hspace{1em}$NoYesYesNo
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Entity W, with a cell wall, cytoplasm, and genetic material, strongly indicates that it is a cell, the basic unit of life. It is likely a prokaryotic cell.
Entity X is only reported to have RNA with a protein coat surrounding it. This description best matches that of a virus. Viruses are not considered living organisms.
Entity Y contains membrane-bound compartments, which are indicative of eukaryotic organelles and DNA. This description is likely describing a eukaryotic cell.
Entity Z is only DNA without any barrier to the outside and does not describe a cell.
Choice A is correct because it correctly identifies Entities W and Y as likely to be classified as living, while X and Z are classified as non-living. Choice B, Choice C, and Choice D do not have this combination of entities.

list.title: Question 65
list.content: - Outline the features of cells that do not conform to the cell theory. [3] - Use named species to explain how unicellular organisms carry out processes of life. [4] - Compare and contrast the structure of prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. [8]
list.markScheme: - Any three from the following: $\ce{ -> }$ mature red blood cells do not have a nucleus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ striated muscle cells have many nuclei [1] $\ce{ -> }$ giant algal cells can be seen without a microscope OR giant algal cells are very large [1] $\ce{ -> }$ aseptate fungal hyphae OR fungal hyphae OR Mucor are multinucleate [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phloem sieve tube elements lack nuclei OR do not have many organelles OR have continuous cytoplasm flowing through adjacent cells OR have sieve tube elements to provide metabolic support OR are interconnected cells. [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Mature red blood cells do not have a nucleus ($\checkmark$), mature sieve tube elements do not have a nucleus ($\checkmark$) and striated muscle cells and fungal hyphae have many nuclei ($\checkmark$). - Any four of the following characteristics and a correct way the chosen unicellular organism carries out that process: $\ce{ -> }$ cilia allow movement in Paramecium OR flagella allow movement in Chlamydomonas OR any other suitable mode of movement relevant to a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ contractile vacuole helps to regulate water potential of the cell OR contractile vacuole has a role in homeostasis in Paramecium OR contractile vacuole helps to regulate water potential of the cell OR contractile vacuole has a role in homeostasis in Chlamydomonas OR any other mechanism of homeostasis that is relevant to a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ oral groove allows nutrition in Paramecium OR nutrition is by photosynthesis in Chlamydomonas OR correct mode of nutrition for a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Paramecium can reproduce asexually by binary fission OR Paramecium can reproduce by conjugation OR Chlorella produce asexually by mitosis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ anal groove allows excretion in Paramecium OR excretion is by contractile vacuoles in Chlamydomonas OR correct mode of excretion for a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ growth of Paramecium occurs after cell division OR Chlamydomonas grows before and after cell division OR correct mode of growth for a named unicellular organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Paramecium sense their environment and respond by movement due to the movement of cilia OR Chlamydomonas have an eyespot to detect light OR correct example of sensitivity for a named unicellular organism [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Paramecia are unicellular organisms that can carry out all functions of life. Paramecia have cilia that allow movement ($\checkmark$). Metabolic reactions ($\checkmark$) happen in mitochondria and the cytoplasm. The contractile vacuole helps to regulate the water concentration ($\checkmark$) of Paramecium by releasing excess water. The oral groove takes in food, so it is responsible for nutrition ($\checkmark$). - Any eight of the following: Answer must include at least one similarity and one difference Similarities: $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic AND eukaryotic cells have plasma membranes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic AND eukaryotic cells have cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic AND eukaryotic cells have ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic AND eukaryotic cells have genetic material OR DNA OR RNA [1] Differences: $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells are not compartmentalised BUT eukaryotic cells are compartmentalised [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells do not have membrane-bound organelles BUT eukaryotic cells do have membrane-bound organelles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have DNA in a loop OR plasmid BUT eukaryotes have linear DNA OR chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have 70S ribosomes BUT eukaryotic cells have 80S ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells do not have a true nucleus OR have a nucleoid region BUT eukaryotic cells do have a true nucleus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ all prokaryotic cells have a cell wall BUT not all eukaryotic cells have a cell wall [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic DNA is naked OR not associated with proteins BUT eukaryotic DNA is associated with histone proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells are smaller THAN eukaryotic cells [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have genetic material ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have plasma membranes ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have cytoplasm ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells have ribosomes ($\checkmark$), but prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes, whereas eukaryotic cells have 80S ribosomes ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic cells do not have a true nucleus, but eukaryotic cells do have a true nucleus ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic cells do not have membrane-bound organelles but eukaryotic cells do have membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic cells have DNA in a loop but eukaryotic cells have linear DNA ($\checkmark$). Not all eukaryotic cells have a cell wall but all prokaryotic cells do have a cell wall ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 66
list.content:
Palisade mesophyll cells produce and release large amounts of carbohydrates. Which characteristics would you expect to observe in such cells?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ A high density of mitochondria and a large central vacuole.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ A high density of chloroplasts and an extensive Golgi apparatus.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ A high density of chloroplasts and a large central vacuole.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ A high density of mitochondria and an extensive Golgi apparatus.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Palisade mesophyll cells are cells in the leaves of plants that produce carbohydrates through photosynthesis. Since photosynthesis takes place within chloroplasts, these cells contain a high density of chloroplasts They also contain a large central vacuole, which occupies the space at the center of the cell and helps maintain the turgor pressure in the cell. The position of the central vacuole ensures the chloroplasts will be pushed near the edges of the cell, where they can receive light. Additionally, the vacuole acts as a storage reservoir for water and other nutrients needed for photosynthesis.
Choice A and Choice D are incorrect because mitochondria are the site of aerobic respiration, during which carbohydrates are broken down to produce ATP. Choice D is also incorrect as the Golgi apparatus packages proteins, not carbohydrates, for export, so Choice B  is also incorrect.

list.title: Question 67
list.content:
Electron microscopes allow the ultrastructure of cells and molecules to be viewed.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8564a2e7-66e0-439e-833c-7a0231698c9e/images/76aa3366-9f58-474e-b864-27e972cea989/Edit.png)


[Source: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)/NIH (2019, January 4). Electron micrograph of tau clusters (46603522841).jpg. Wikimedia. Retrieved December 27, 2024, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_micrograph_of_tau_clusters_(46603522841).jpg. Public Domain]

Which of these methods is used to analyse protein structure?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Freeze-fracture electron microscopy
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Fluorescent staining
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Cryogenic electron microscopy
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Immunofluorescence
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because cryogenic electron microscopy can produce 3D images of biological molecules such as proteins, DNA, and RNA. Samples are rapidly frozen to preserve their natural state before an electron beam is passed through, allowing the structure of individual molecules to be studied.
Choice A is incorrect because freeze-fracture electron microscopy is primarily used to study cellular structures, such as the internal arrangement of membranes. While it involves rapid freezing and can produce 3D images, it does not resolve molecular or atomic details of protein structures.
Choice B is incorrect because fluorescent staining is used in light microscopy to identify specific molecules, such as proteins, in cells. Fluorescent dyes or antibodies emit specific wavelengths of light, highlighting target molecules, but they do not provide detailed structural information about proteins.
Choice D is incorrect because immunofluorescence identifies specific proteins in cells or tissues using fluorescently tagged antibodies. While it is useful for locating proteins, it is not a technique for analysing protein structure at the molecular level.

list.title: Question 68
list.content: The light micrographs below show examples of skeletal muscle, phloem sieve tube elements, aseptate fungal hyphae, and red blood cells. These types of cells are sometimes used as atypical examples of cells. Retrieved 02:14, April 9, 2025 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File.jpg&oldid=933116797.] - Explain how the number of nuclei in each cell type in the micrograph of each cell relates to the cell’s function. [4] - Contrast the cell wall composition of the aseptate hyphae and phloem sieve tube elements. [1]
list.markScheme: - to award a mark, the response must include the number of nuclei AND a reason for this $\ce{ -> }$ skeletal muscle cells have multiple nuclei, providing multiple copies of genes to produce the large numbers of proteins needed for muscle contraction [1] $\ce{ -> }$ phloem sieve tube elements lack a nucleus (at maturity), which creates space for the efficient transport of sugars and other organic molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ aseptate fungal hyphae have multiple nuclei to allow for rapid growth OR distribution of nutrients OR cytoplasmic streaming throughout the extensive network OR multinucleation occurs due to nuclear divisions without cytoplasmic division [1] $\ce{ -> }$ red blood cells lack a nucleus, which increases space for haemoglobin, maximising oxygen transport [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Skeletal muscle cells have many nuclei because they must make many copies of proteins for contractions along the entire length of the cell, which may be very long ($\checkmark$). Phloem sieve tube elements have no nucleus to allow for more space for transporting sugars more efficiently ($\checkmark$). Aseptate hyphae have many nuclei throughout the cell to help it grow quickly and distribute nutrients ($\checkmark$). Red blood cells have no nuclei at maturity for greater volume to carry haemoglobin ($\checkmark$). Note a table showing the comparisons would also be acceptable: CellNo. of nucleiRelation to cell functionSkeletal musclemanyfor many copies of protein synthesis($\checkmark$)Phloem sieve tube elementsnoneto allow room for translocation($\checkmark$)Aseptate fungal hyphaemanyto allow rapid transfer of nutrients($\checkmark$)Red blood cellnoneto create more room for haemoglobin($\checkmark$) - $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ fungal cell walls are composed of chitin, WHEREAS plant cell walls are composed of cellulose [1] [1 mark maximum] $\hspace{1em}$ $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: $\hspace{1em}$ Fungal cell walls are composed of chitin, while plant cell walls are composed of cellulose ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 69
list.content: - Outline one way unicellular organisms can carry out each of nutrition, movement and excretion. [3] - Draw a single mitochondrion, and annotate it to outline the role of four labelled structures. [5] - Compare and contrast the structure of E. coli and a palisade mesophyll cell. [7]
list.markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ nutrition by diffusion through cell membrane OR engulfment OR phagocytosis OR endocytosis OR photosynthesis OR digestion by enzymes in vacuoles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ movement by cilia OR flagella OR pseudopodia [1] $\ce{ -> }$ excretion by simple diffusion OR active transport OR exocytosis OR contractile vacuoles OR vacuoles storing OR isolating waste before removal [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Unicellular organisms carry out the processes of life in varying ways. They can carry out nutrition by engulfing the nutrients ($\checkmark$) from their surroundings, they can move using flagella ($\checkmark$), and they can remove wastes from the cell by simple diffusion ($\checkmark$). - Diagram must include four of the following labels and annotations: $\ce{ -> }$ outer membrane protective barrier OR contains transport proteins that allow specific molecules to enter the mitochondrion [1] $\ce{ -> }$ inner membrane OR cristae increase surface area for reactions OR contains proteins essential for reactions OR ATP production [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA encodes genes essential for mitochondrial functioning [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 70S ribosomes for synthesis of proteins required by mitochondrion [1] $\ce{ -> }$ matrix contains enzymes for chemical reactions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ intermembrane space - allows build-up of protons OR ion gradient for ATP synthesis OR chemiosmosis OR contains enzymes for chemical reactions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ clear drawing with no sketchy lines and of suitable size [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ba177021-8efc-4ac3-8984-af65f603bc24/images/51530aa5-3ec2-45cc-8701-1d4b4fd4ec74/BI1049.png) [© Revision village 2022] - Any seven of the following (must contain at least one similarity and/or one difference): $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH E.coli and palisade mesophyll cells have cell OR plasma membranes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH E.coli and palisade mesophyll cells have cytoplasm [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH E.coli and palisade mesophyll cells have a cell wall [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH E.coli and palisade mesophyll cells contain ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ E.coli cell wall is made up of peptidoglycan WHEREAS palisade mesophyll cell walls are made of cellulose [1] $\ce{ -> }$ palisade mesophyll cells have a compartmentalised structure WHEREAS E.coli do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ palisade mesophyll cells have 80S ribosomes WHEREAS E.coli have 70S [1] $\ce{ -> }$ palisade mesophyll cells have nuclei WHEREAS E.coli have a nucleoid [1] $\ce{ -> }$ E.coli can have plasmids OR circular DNA WHEREAS palisade mesophyll cells have linear DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ E.coli have external structures such as flagella OR pili BUT palisade mesophyll cells do not [1] $\ce{ -> }$ palisade mesophyll cells have membrane bound organelles such as golgi apparatus, rough endoplasmic reticulum, chloroplasts, mitochondria WHEREAS E.coli do not [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Palisade mesophyll cells and E.coli both have cell membranes ($\checkmark$) and cytoplasm ($\checkmark$). They also both can have cell walls ($\checkmark$), however the cell wall in E.coli is composed of peptidoglycan, whereas the cell wall in palisade mesophyll cells is composed of cellulose ($\checkmark$). Palisade mesophyll cells are full of membrane bound organelles such as the golgi apparatus, which gives them a compartmentalised structure, whereas E.coli do not have a compartmentalised structure or membrane bound organelles ($\checkmark$). Both palisade mesophyll cells and E.coli have ribosomes ($\checkmark$), but E.coli have 70S ribosomes and palisade mesophyll cells have 80S ribosomes ($\checkmark$). DNA is also stored differently in palisade mesophyll cells and E.coli. Palisade mesophyll cells store their DNA inside the nucleus and it has a linear structure, whereas E.coli have DNA floating freely in the cytoplasm as a nucleoid ($\checkmark$) and can sometimes contain extra DNA in the form of a plasmid ($\checkmark$). E.coli can also have external structures such as pili or flagella ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 70
list.content: Below is a diagram of Saccharomyces cervesiae commonly referred to as Brewer's yeast. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d48038b1-43cc-4f2a-a666-47ce7e1443d1/images/42c78d0e-6ccf-4251-81a8-22cd1b96d088/BI2438.png) [© RevisionVillage2025. Created with BioRender.com] - Distinguish between the cell wall in fungal and plant cells. [1] - - Explain the presence of chloroplast in plant cells, but not animal or fungal cells. [2] - A chloroplast is a type of plastid. Outline the function of one other named type of plastid found in plant cells that is absent in fungal cells. [1]
list.markScheme: - $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ fungal cell walls are primarily composed of chitin WHEREAS plant cell walls are composed of cellulose [1] [1 mark maximum] $\hspace{1em}$ $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: $\hspace{1em}$ The major component of fungal cell walls is chitin, but in plants, it’s cellulose ($\checkmark$). - - any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ plants use chloroplasts for photosynthesis AND are autotrophs OR allows plants to make their own food OR convert light energy to chemical energy [1] $\ce{ -> }$ animals and fungi do not need chloroplast to photosynthesise because they are heterotrophs OR feed on other organisms OR obtain energy by consuming organic matter rather than producing it [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Plants are autotrophs and make their own food by photosynthesis. Chloroplasts contain chlorophyll which absorbs the light energy needed for photosynthesis ($\checkmark$). Animals and fungi are heterotrophs, they consume their food and do not need chloroplast for photosynthesis ($\checkmark$). - the following: $\ce{ -> }$ chromoplasts synthesise OR store pigments (other than chlorophyll) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ leucoplasts are involved in storage OR metabolism [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Plant cells have chromoplasts which synthesise and store pigments, such as carotenoids ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 71
list.content:
The diagram depicts a single-celled organism living in freshwater that faces water constantly moving into its cell due to osmosis.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e5d92e73-ab20-43da-aee4-b427dbf75796/images/c2bb4cec-e54b-4a2c-8f44-13ddf6b20f8d/BI2792.png)


[Source: Adapted from File: Paramecium caudatum.svg. (2024, March 12). Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 04:34, April 23, 2025 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File.svg&oldid=859786930.CC Public Domain]

To prevent bursting, the cell actively pumps out excess water using specialised structures. This process is an example of:



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Obtaining nutrients
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Eliminating waste products
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Responding to external stimuli
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Maintaining homeostasis
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Homeostasis is the maintenance of a stable internal environment. The organism pumping out of excess water is a mechanism to keep its osmolarity stable and different from the outside of the cell. Therefore, Choice D is correct.
The organism is not taking in or making any substance for energy and growth, so Choice A is incorrect.
Excess water may be considered a waste product. However, the primary purpose of the pump is to regulate osmolarity and prevent lysis. Waste products typically refer to metabolic wastes like carbon dioxide or nitrogenous compounds. Therefore, Choice B is incorrect.
The active pumping out of water is the organism's way of maintaining internal conditions rather than just a direct response to the stimulus, and so Choice C is incorrect.

list.title: Question 72
list.content: - Outline the role of auxin in positive phototropism. [3] - Explain the evidence that supports the theory that eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells. [5] - Explain how the products of the light-dependent stage of photosynthesis are used in the light-independent stage to convert carbon dioxide into organic substances. [7]
list.markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ light is detected by group of proteins OR phototropins which trigger the movement of auxins by active transport [1] $\ce{ -> }$ auxin efflux pumps move auxin so the concentration of auxins is more on the shadier side and lesser on the side with more light [1] $\ce{ -> }$ plant cells have auxin receptors [1] $\ce{ -> }$ when auxin binds to these receptors ,transcription of genes for enzyme OR expansin [1] $\ce{ -> }$ auxin causes movement of hydrogen ions from cytoplasm into the cell walls [1] $\ce{ -> }$ hydrogen ions and expansion OR enzyme loosens cellulose fibres OR fibres of cell wall [1] $\ce{ -> }$ causes cells on the shaded side of shoot tip to elongate [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Light is detected by phototropins and this triggers the movement of auxins by active transport ($\checkmark$). Auxin efflux pumps move auxins from cytoplasm into cell walls, so that the concentration of auxin is more on the shadier side ($\checkmark$) and less on the side with more light. When auxin binds to receptors on the cells, genes for the enzyme expansin are expressed ($\checkmark$). Expansin, and the pumping of protons from the cytoplasm into the cell wall cause the loosening of cellulose fibres ($\checkmark$) in the cell walls, leading to elongation of the cells ($\checkmark$). - Any five of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ theory of endosymbiosis proposes that mitochondria OR chloroplasts have evolved from free-living prokaryotes that were engulfed OR taken in by endocytosis, by larger cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts have naked DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts divide by binary fission [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts divide independently of cell cycle OR cell [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts about same size as prokaryotes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts have 70S ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts can synthesise their own proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts have double membranes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria OR chloroplasts have inner membrane like OR similar in structure to prokaryotes AND outer membrane like OR similar in structure to eukaryotes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ DNA of mitochondria OR chloroplasts is more closely related OR more similar to prokaryotic DNA than to nuclear DNA of eukaryotic cells, OR rRNA OR ribosomal RNA more closely related OR more similar to prokaryotes than eukaryotes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ observations of modern examples of endosymbiosis OR given examples of present day endosymbiosis, provide support for the theory [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The endosymbiotic theory supports the evidence that mitochondria and chloroplasts in eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells, which were taken in by larger cells through endocytosis ($\checkmark$). The evidence supporting this theory includes the fact that these organelles have naked DNA ($\checkmark$), divide by binary fission ($\checkmark$), can synthesise their own proteins ($\checkmark$) and have double membranes around the outside ($\checkmark$). - Any seven of the following: (drawing showing the Calvin cycle with the steps described below): $\ce{ -> }$ products of the light-dependent reaction are essential for the light-independent reactions [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light-dependent reactions produce ATP, NADPH and oxygen [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ATP and NADPH are used in the light-independent reactions OR Calvin cycle [1] $\ce{ -> }$ light-independent reactions convert carbon dioxide into glucose and other organic molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ enzyme RuBisCO fixes carbon dioxide [1] $\ce{ -> }$ causes 1 x RuBP to bind to 1 x carbon dioxide [1] $\ce{ -> }$ 6 C compound is unstable and forms two 3C compounds of glycerate-3-phosphate OR GP [1] $\ce{ -> }$ ATP and NADPH are used to convert glycerate-3-phosphate OR GP to triose phosphate OR TP [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some of the triose phosphate OR TP leaves the cycle to form carbohydrates, most is used to reform RuBP [1] $\ce{ -> }$ regeneration of RuBP requires energy in the form of ATP [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis produce ATP, NADPH ($\checkmark$) and oxygen. Oxygen is a by-product, ATP and NADPH are used in the light-independent reactions. In the stroma of the chloroplast, carbon dioxide combines with RuBP ($\checkmark$), a 5C compound catalysed by the enzyme Rubisco ($\checkmark$). The 6C compound formed is unstable and splits into two molecules of glycerate-3-phosphate ($\checkmark$). ATP and NADPH ($\checkmark$) are used to convert glycerate-3-phosphate into triose phosphate ($\checkmark$). Some of the molecules of triose phosphate leave the cycle to form glucose ($\checkmark$) or other carbohydrates, most of it is used to regenerate the 5C RuBP ($\checkmark$). Regeneration of RuBP again requires ATP ($\checkmark$) obtained from the light-dependent reactions. $\underline{\textrm{For additional detail}}$: see 5:26 in Photosynthesis Key Concept Video: https://www.revisionvillage.com/ib-biology/hl/key-concepts/?keyConceptId=cd710a11-a37d-4f93-aed3-30e4e1d75e55 A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 73
list.content: - Distinguish between the structure and location of chromosomes found in eukaryotes and prokaryotes. [5] - Describe the stages of meiosis and how genetically unique, haploid gametes are created during the process. [7] - Explain the information that can be deduced from a human karyogram. [3]
list.markScheme: - Any five of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ eukaryotic chromosomes are found in the nucleus WHEREAS prokaryotic chromosomes are found in the nucleoid region OR chromosomes of eukaryotes are contained within a membrane WHEREAS prokaryotic chromosomes are not membrane bound [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotes have a circular chromosome WHEREAS eukaryotes have linear chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotes typically have one chromosome WHEREAS eukaryotes typically have multiple chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ in eukaryotic chromosomes, DNA is associated with histone proteins WHEREAS prokaryotic chromosomes do not contain histones [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic chromosomes do not contain centromeres WHEREAS eukaryotic chromosomes do [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic chromosomes do not contain telomeres WHEREAS eukaryotic chromosomes do [1] $\ce{ -> }$ eukaryotic chromosomes carry more genetic information OR DNA OR genes THAN prokaryotic chromosomes [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Eukaryotic chromosomes are found in the nucleus whereas prokaryotic chromosomes are found in the nucleoid region ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotes typically contain one, circular chromosome ($\checkmark$) whereas eukaryotes have multiple, linear chromosomes ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic chromosomes do not contain centromeres and telomeres ($\checkmark$), whereas eukaryotic chromosomes do ($\checkmark$). - Any seven of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ all the DNA in a cell is replicated during interphase [1] $\ce{ -> }$ so cells are diploid OR contain homologous chromosomes when they enter meiosis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes pair AND become visible OR condense in prophase I [1] $\ce{ -> }$ crossing over occurs between the non-sister chromatids of homologous chromosomes during prophase I [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are moved to the equator of the cell by spindle microtubules AND randomly orientated OR independently assorted in metaphase I [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are pulled to opposite sides of the cell by spindle microtubules in anaphase I [1] $\ce{ -> }$ one diploid cell is split into two haploid cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chromatids condense OR become visible during prophase II [1] $\ce{ -> }$ pairs of sister chromatids are moved to the equator of the cell by spindle microtubules during metaphase II AND randomly orientated OR independently assorted [1] $\ce{ -> }$ pairs of sister chromatids are separated by spindle fibres in anaphase II [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nuclear membrane reforms in telophase II AND four haploid cells are formed from the two haploid cells of meiosis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ crossing over during prophase I AND independent assortment OR random alignment of homologous chromosomes in metaphase I OR metaphase II result in unique gametes [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: All of the DNA in a cell is replicated during interphase ($\checkmark$), so cells are diploid when they enter meiosis ($\checkmark$). Homologous chromosomes pair up, become visible ($\checkmark$) and crossing over of non-sister chromatids occur during prophase I ($\checkmark$). Then, homologous chromosomes are moved to the equator of the cell by spindle microtubules and randomly orientated during metaphase I ($\checkmark$). Homologous chromosomes are pulled to the opposite poles of the cell by spindle fibres in anaphase I ($\checkmark$) and one diploid cell is split into two haploid cells during telophase I ($\checkmark$). The cells then enter meiosis II. The pairs of sister chromatids are independently assorted to form a single line along the equator of the cell, in metaphase II ($\checkmark$). During anaphase II the centromeres split and the sister chromatids are pulled to opposite poles of the cell ($\checkmark$). In telophase II the nuclear membrane reforms around the chromosomes, and after cytokinesis, 4 new haploid, non-identical, daughter cells are formed from the 2 haploid cells that resulted from meiosis I ($\checkmark$). - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ a karyogram is an image showing the positions of centromeres and banding patterns of stained OR dyed homologous chromosomes ordered by decreasing length [1] $\ce{ -> }$ biological sex determined by XX and XY OR sex chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ whether non-disjunction has occurred is determined by the presence or absence of chromosome (s) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ presence of chromosomal abnormalities (such as breakages or translocation) determined by the banding pattern OR size of chromosome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ indication of chromosome disorders such as Down syndrome, which is caused by trisomy 21[1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: A karyogram is an image showing the positions of centromeres and banding patterns of stained homologous chromosomes ordered by decreasing length ($\checkmark$). A karyogram can be used to deduce biological sex ($\checkmark$) or the presence of chromosomal abnormalities ($\checkmark$). A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.content: The diagram below shows a cell. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e319f2ff-2759-4a29-a432-86b278d912d1/images/921bf923-691c-4540-aaea-d868eb9c341e/BI0805A.png) [Source: Adapted from Gonzalez, R., & Kerfeld, C. (2022, June 13). Synechococcus elongatus. Wikipedia. Retrieved June 19, 2022, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synechococcus_elongatus Copyright under CC BY 3.0] - Compare and contrast the structure of a mictochondrion with the structure of the cell shown in the diagram. [2] - Explain why the cell in the diagram is structurally similar to a mitochondrion.[2]
list.markScheme: - Any two of the following: Similarities $\ce{ -> }$ both have plasma membranes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both contain circular OR naked DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondrial ribosomes are more similar in size OR structure to prokaryotes than eukaryotes OR both contain 70S ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both are similar in size [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both are similar shapes OR oval OR elongated [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both have ATPase proteins embedded in surrounding membrane [1] Differences $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria do not have a cell wall OR a capsule whereas, prokaryotes do [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotes may have flagella OR pili but mitochondria do not [1] Answer must include at least one difference and one similarity to gain full marks [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The cell in the diagram is a prokaryotic cell and is similar in structure to a mitochondrion, as mitochondrial ribosomes are more similar in size and structure to prokaryotes than eukaryotes, ($\checkmark$), and they both have naked circular DNA ($\checkmark$). However mitochondria do not have a cell wall ($\checkmark$), whereas prokaryotic cells do. - Any two of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ endosymbiotic theory [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria evolved from free-living prokaryotes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ that were engulfed BUT not digested by larger prokaryotes [1] [2 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The prokaryotic cell in the diagram has structural similarities to a mitochondrion, due to the endosymbiotic theory ($\checkmark$) which explains that mitochondria evolved from free-living prokaryotes ($\checkmark$) that were engulfed though not digested ($\checkmark$) by larger cells.

list.title: Question 75
list.content:
What is the correct magnification of this image?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07e9979a-f2b9-4ab8-a9ce-3e18e0fd6058/images/f345e14c-8773-402b-bcc4-ddb8b6a5d28c/bi0752.png)


[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia (2006, March 1). File Microscope Siemens, 1960.jpg - wikimedia commons. Wikimedia commons. Retrieved March 4, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscope_Siemens,_1960.jpg Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 1000 x
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 100 x
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 0.1 x
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 10000 x
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Magnification is calculated using the equation image size divided by actual size. Both numbers must be the same units. The image size of the magnification bar is 5 mm, or 5000 µm, the actual size of the magnification bar is 5 µm. 5000 µm ÷ 5 µm = 1000 x. Choice A is correct.
Choices B, C and D are incorrect.

Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ diagram must contain a large angular shape, with a labelled nucleus, cell membrane AND cell wall [1] Labels: $\ce{ -> }$ 80S ribosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ mitochondria [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Golgi apparatus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ rough endoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ vacuole [1] $\ce{ -> }$ smooth endoplasmic reticulum [1] $\ce{ -> }$ nucleolus [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/529d9d46-e561-4668-8935-82e7109e4e46/images/8faf0774-fe1b-4373-96af-b3753ade307b/BI0816ANSCOR.png) [© Revision Village 2023] - Any one of the following $\ce{ -> }$ the light was off OR not bright enough OR diaphragm was not open enough [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the cell was not directly below the lens [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the microscope was not focused sufficiently [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the slide OR coverslip was too dirty [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the objective lens was not clicked in correctly OR not appropriately housed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the lens OR eyepiece was dirty [1] [1 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The student may not have been able to see the cell as it was not placed directly below the lens ($\checkmark$).

list.title: Question 77
list.content: - Electron microscopy provides images of cells with significantly higher resolution when compared to light microscopy. Evaluate the implications and limitations of relying primarily on electron micrographs to understand cell function. [3] - Explain how advances in microscopy have contributed to our understanding of cell structure and function. [4] - Discuss the evidence for and against the idea that prokaryotic cells are “simple” compared to eukaryotic cells. [8]
list.markScheme: - any three of the following, must include at least one implication and one limitation Implications $\ce{ -> }$ fine detail resolution has led to a more detailed understanding of structure-function relationships [1] $\ce{ -> }$ discovery of new organelles and structures [1] Limitations $\ce{ -> }$ requires complex sample preparation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ sample preparation can leave artefacts [1] $\ce{ -> }$ samples must be fixed, dead, meaning no dynamic cellular processes can be observed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ pigmentation or colour is not detected [1] $\ce{ -> }$ maximum understanding comes from combining information from both light and electron microscopy [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Electron microscopy gives us very detailed images, which let us see how the tiny parts of a cell are structured to fulfil their functions ($\checkmark$). It has also led to the discovery of new things inside cells ($\checkmark$). Unfortunately, to prepare specimens for electron microscopy, they must be treated in such a way that they are killed, and so we cannot observe processes happening in real time ($\checkmark$). - any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ light microscopy allowed for the initial visualisation of cells and basic structures [1] $\ce{ -> }$ staining techniques have enhanced the visibility of cell components [1] $\ce{ -> }$ fluorescence microscopy enables visualisation and localisation of specific molecules [1] $\ce{ -> }$ live-imaging techniques allow dynamic processes to be observed [1] $\ce{ -> }$ electron microscopy provides significantly higher resolution than light microscopy [1] $\ce{ -> }$ transmission electron microscopy reveals details of the internal structure of organelles [1] $\ce{ -> }$ scanning electron microscopy provides 3-D images of cell surfaces OR cell shape [1] [4 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Light microscopy first allowed us to see cells and their basic parts ($\checkmark$). Later, staining made it easier to see these parts more clearly ($\checkmark$). Fluorescence microscopy has allowed scientists to visualise and pinpoint the locations of specific molecules within cells ($\checkmark$). Electron microscopy provides far greater resolution than light microscopy ($\checkmark$), making it possible to see internal structures like mitochondria and membranes in fine detail ($\checkmark$). - any eight of the following: In favour $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles OR have less compartmentalisation [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have a single, circular chromosome; eukaryotic cells have multiple linear chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells are generally smaller [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells reproduce by binary fission, which is less complex than mitosis/meiosis [1] Against $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells efficiently carry out all life processes within a single cell, demonstrating functional sophistication [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells exhibit diverse and complex metabolic pathways [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells exhibit unique metabolic pathways, ie chemosynthesis [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells can engage in cell signaling [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have highly specialised adaptations (ie flagellae) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells have a high surface area to volume ratio, increasing the exchange rate with the surroundings [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic cells are structurally simpler but functionally complex [1] $\ce{ -> }$ evaluation of the application of the word “simple” [1] [8 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Prokaryotes are generally smaller ($\checkmark$) than most eukaryotic cells, and they reproduce by binary fission ($\checkmark$) instead of mitosis or meiosis. Prokaryotic cells are often called more simple than eukaryotic cells, but it is important to distinguish between structure and function ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic cells may appear simple, but they still carry out all of the functions of life ($\checkmark$) and have some that are unique to prokaryotes. Although prokaryotes do not have membrane-bound organelles ($\checkmark$), they still have complex metabolic pathways like cellular respiration and even pathways eukaryotes do not have, like chemosynthesis ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotes can communicate with each other via cell signalling pathways like quorum sensing ($\checkmark$) and also have highly specialised structures such as flagellae for motility ($\checkmark$). The term “simple” is an oversimplification of a superficial observation. A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information. [1]

list.title: Question 78
list.content:
Which characteristic is not true for both mitochondria and chloroplasts?



- A.	$\hspace{1em}$ They are present in both eukaryotes and prokaryotes.
- B.	$\hspace{1em}$ They are both able to self replicate.
- C.	$\hspace{1em}$ They are both able to synthesise proteins.
- D.	$\hspace{1em}$ They both contain circular DNA.
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Chloroplasts and mitochondria are present only in eukaryotes. Therefore Choice A  is the correct answer.
Mitochondria and chloroplasts are both able to self replicate (Choice B), synthesise proteins (Choice C) and contain circular DNA (Choice D).

list.title: Question 79
list.content:
A researcher labelled two different proteins with molecules that emit light of distinct colours when illuminated with a specific wavelength of light. To determine if these proteins are present in the same location in the cell, which type of microscopy would be most appropriate?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Bright field microscopy
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Scanning electron microscopy
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Fluorescence microscopy
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Transmission electron microscopy
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Fluorescence microscopy uses specific wavelengths of light to excite fluorescent molecules, the labels, causing them to emit light at different wavelengths. Using appropriate filters, the light emitted from each can be detected to determine their locations. Therefore, Choice C is correct.
Bright field microscopy is the term used to describe a common light microscopy technique where specimens appear dark against a bright background due to the direct transmission of light through the sample. Bright field microscopy would not be able to excite specific fluorescent molecules or distinguish between particular wavelengths of light, so Choice A is incorrect.
Scanning electron microscopy uses a stream of electrons to produce an image of the surface of an organism and does not use or detect any wavelength of light, so Choice B is incorrect.
Transmission electron microscopy passes a stream of electrons through a thin specimen to visualise internal structures and does not use or detect any wavelength of light, so Choice D is incorrect.

list.title: Question 80
list.content:
The electron micrograph shows a prokaryotic cell, Cyclotella litoralis. What is the actual diameter of the cell in this image?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ba4f9e8b-a955-4426-94f3-bb5346da7d37/images/2c24792a-990f-42ed-8bfd-64f98a3ec8d6/bi0753.png)


[Source: Adapted from FWC Fish and Wildlife Research Institute. (2011, June 7). Cyclotella litoralis (scanning electron micrograph). Flickr. Retrieved March 5, 2023, from https://www.flickr.com/photos/myfwc/5808259556 Copyright under CC BY 3.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 3.5 cm
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 350 µm
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 3500 mm
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 35 µm
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The diameter of the cell is the total length, along the widest part of the cell; 3.5 cm. When the scale bar, which represents 10 µm, is measured, it is shown to be 1 cm long in the image. 3.5 multiplied by 10 is 35 µm.  Choice D is correct.
Choices A, B and C are incorrect.

list.title: Question 81
list.content:
The electron micrograph shows an animal cell.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c20571c4-6842-4912-a7e1-398718059786/images/f9bda846-23e1-46a3-9bb6-07cc25ae04cd/BI0416i_1.5.png)

[Source: Adapted from Itayba, Hebrew Wikipedia. (2016, March 1). Category: Electron Microscope Images. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved May 19, 2022, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Electron_microscopy.jpg. Copyright under CC-SA 3.0]

Which organelle's origin is due to the endosymbiosis of ancient cells?
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D has visible cristae and is oval-shaped; it is a mitochondrion, it evolved as a consequence of endosymbiosis.
Choice A  is the cytoplasm, Choice B is the nucleus, and Choice C is a vacuole. Only the mitochondria and chloroplasts' origin are explained by endosymbiotic theory.

list.title: Question 82
list.content:
The electron micrograph shows a sarcomere, the smallest functional unit of striated muscle tissue. What is the actual length between the two Z lines?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c4757206-7907-4040-94a2-08079ed88b94/images/b762a3a8-46a3-4d64-a154-328e5b7831c2/BI0562i.png)


[Source: Adapted from Loison, O., Weitkunat , M., Kaya-Çopur , A., Nascimento Alves, C., Matzat , T., & Spletter , M. L. (2018). Category: sarcomeres. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved March 5, 2023, from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category Copyright under CC BY 3.0][Ruler tool, cm]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ 10 µm
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 mm
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 cm
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ 1 µm
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The length between the two Z lines is 4.5 cm, which is equivalent to 45000 µm. Actual length is calculated using the equation; image size divided by magnification. 45000 µm ÷ 45000 x = 1 µm.  Choice D is correct.
Choices A, B and C are incorrect.

list.title: Question 83
list.content:
A student, learning to use a microscope, observed a pollen grain under a microscope with a magnification of ×100. Using an eyepiece graticule, they measured the diameter of the pollen grain to be 25 divisions. At this magnification, 1 division on the eyepiece graticule equals 3 $\mu$m. To allow the student to measure more pollen grains and to calculate a mean diameter, which of the following conclusions on the experimental work so far is/are correct?


- I. $\hspace{1em}$	Increasing the magnification of the objective lens would widen the field of view.
- II. $\hspace{.7em}$	The actual diameter of the pollen grain is 75 $\mu$m.
- III. $\hspace{.5em}$	If the magnification were increased to ×200, each eyepiece graticule division would represent a smaller actual size.
 



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is not true. Increasing the magnification will narrow the field of view. This is a common student mistake. As magnification increases, the observer is focusing on a smaller area, like zooming in with a camera.
Statement II is true. The actual diameter of the pollen grain is calculated as 25 divisions × 3 µm/division = 75 µm.
Statement III is true. If the magnification were increased by switching to a higher power objective, the same number of eyepiece graticule divisions would span a smaller actual distance on the specimen.
Choice C is correct because it contains the proper combination of Statement II and Statement III. Choice A, Choice B and Choice D do not contain the proper combination of statements.

list.title: Question 84
list.content:
Which organelle is formed by a vesicle derived from the cell membrane?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Food vacuole
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Ribosome
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Golgi apparatus
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Smooth endoplasmic reticulum
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
When a cell takes in material through endocytosis, it produces a vesicle derived from the cell membrane, which is how a food vacuole is formed.
Ribosomes are involved in translation (Choice B), the golgi apparatus sorts, packages and modifies proteins (Choice C) and the smooth endoplasmic reticulum, among other functions, synthesizes lipids (Choice D).

list.title: Question 85
list.content:
Which organism contains DNA in just two different types of organelle?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ A tree
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ A mushroom
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ An Archaeon
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ A seaweed
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
All eukaryotic organisms contain organismal DNA in the cell nucleus and mitochondrial DNA in the mitochondria. Photosynthetic organisms additionally contain DNA in the chloroplasts. So, an organism that is a eukaryote but not photosynthetic contains DNA in exactly two organelles. A mushroom is a non-photosynthetic eukaryote, so a mushroom contains DNA in exactly two organelles.
A tree (Choice A) and a seaweed (Choice D) each contain DNA in three organelles (nucleus, mitochondria, and chloroplasts). An Archaeon (Choice C) lacks membrane-bound organelles; its DNA is contained within the cytoplasm.

list.content: The transmission electron micrograph shows a mammalian lung mitochondrion. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/41f321d5-0261-4fba-bcb0-2e3fb88623aa/images/e10333bb-cac0-4d33-981b-2f0a615266a4/BI2799.png) [Source: Adapted from Howard, L (n.d.). Mitochondria,mammalian_lung-_TEM [Photograph]. Wikimedia Commons. Retrieved 5 Sept. 2024 from https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File: Mitochondria,mammalian_lung-_TEM.jpg. Copyright Public Domain] - Draw an annotated diagram of the mitochondrion to scale. [4] - Calculate the magnification of this image. [2]
list.markScheme: - $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ drawing shape resembles the image, including overall outline and internal structures [1] $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ single lines, no sketched lines, no shading [1] $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ matrix correctly labelled AND site of Krebs cycle OR contains enzymes for Krebs cycle OR metabolic reactions OR provides medium for substrate-enzymes interaction OR any other suitable function of matrix [1] $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ crista correctly labelled AND increases surface area for electron transport chain OR ATP synthases OR oxidative phosphorylation OR site of ATP production [1] [4 marks maximum] $\hspace{1em}$ $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/41f321d5-0261-4fba-bcb0-2e3fb88623aa/images/8364d878-f1be-4671-8d89-5ba5007819cc/Ans.png) - $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ measured length of scale bar divided by 50 nm for magnification calculation OR $\dfrac{7,000,000}{\ce{50 nm}}$ (accept image line length in range 6,000,000 - 8,000,000 nm) [1] $\hspace{1em}$ $\ce{ -> }$ 140,000 $\times$ (accept answers in range 120,000 - 160,000 x) [1] [2 marks maximum] $\hspace{1em}$ $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: $\hspace{1em}$ Length of scale bar in image = 7 mm $\hspace{1em}$ 1mm = 1,000,000 nm $\hspace{1em}$ 7mm = 7,000,000 nm $\hspace{1em}$ Actual length scale bar represents = 50 nm $\hspace{1em}$ Magnification = $\dfrac{\mathbf{7,000,000}}{\mathbf{50\ nm}}$ ($\checkmark$) = 140,000 $\times$ ($\checkmark$)
